description.text: Coupler that fits inside PVC (or whatever) pipe. Half a coupler, actually, so it can be easily printed and then glued together. This one is designed for a slip fit within 3/4" Schedule 40 pipe, and it has a thin raft-like flange around the perimeter to minimize warping. Dimensions are easily adjusted using variables in the OpenSCAD file.

• If you'll need something other that a 3/4" Schedule 40 PVC slip fit coupling, edit the OpenSCAD file and modify the variables as desired. Grab the software from openscad.org if you don't have it. The variables to edit are at the top in the first few lines.
    • pipe_id = the outer diameter of the pipe to fit in the coupler, in millimeters (20.93)
    • wall = wall thickness of the pipe, which sets the diameter of the inner ledge (3.25)
    • gap = the clearance between the pipe inner diameter and coupler outer diameter (1.25)
    • flange_w = width of anti-warping flange, or 0 for none (6.0)
    • flange_t = thickness of anti-warping flange (0.2)
  • Save and compile the OpenSCAD file, and generate an STL file.
  • Print two of them. I used Cura 12.07 default settings, PLA, with 20% infill. 190 degrees. Each took a bit over an hour for me.
  • Trim off the flange with a hobby knife. It should come off easily, a minute or two of effort.
  • Glue them together with cyanoacrylate. If they are a bit warped and don't fit perfectly, heat up the flat faces. I put them in a hot pan until they're just hot enough that they aren't quite sticky, then press them together, and wick the glue into the seams.
  • Use.

title: Sharpening Guide for 6" Ryobi Bench Grinder

description.text:
This is a guide for sharpening your knives to a 20% angle on a 6" Ryobi bench grinder using paper sharpening wheels.

I purchased a Ryobi 6" Bench Grinder (BG612G) From Home Depot to sharpen knives using The Razer Sharp Edgemaking System (see: http://nextgen.sharpeningwheels.com). The system is great, but I found that I had trouble getting a consistent edge when free handing the grind. So I turned the wheels around (top of wheel spinning away) and chose to sharpen my blades by holding the flat side level with the ground. In order to know where on the wheel to hold the blade I made these edge-sharpening guides. They screw in place onto the grinder and have an indicator at 20% and 45%. I line up the tip of the arrow with the center of the shaft and hold my blade level with the ground and grind on the wheel on that line. Works like a champ!

description.text:
The Snowflake Generator Tutorial was created as a part of the BlocksCAD® Snowflake Challenge. The desire of this tutorial is to boost interest in the Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics Fields among students. It is the author’s belief that through the development of promotion of these fields, we are creating a better tomorrow for our students.

This tutorial gives students a step by step guide through creating a random snowflake generator. The tutorial is broken into six assignments. Each assignment begins with an introduction to the assignment which pulls in various fields of science and engineering. As a student progresses through the assignments, they are designed to keep the student challenged through an increasing level of difficulty. Examples and illustrations are used to increase the student’s thinking and understanding of how BlocksCAD®, 3D Modeling, and Programming work.

Submitted are the Snowflake Generator Tutorial.pdf and seven XLF files—one to display the result of each assignment of the tutorial and a final “Snowflake Generator.xlm” file. In addition to these files, various pictures have been uploaded to illustrate the various parts of the tutorial and to show 3D printed examples of some of the snowflakes created. Four STL files are provided for the four snowflake 3D prints pictured for the rare case that someone desires to print these snowflakes without going through the tutorial.

A complete list of the BlocksCAD® Tools used in this Tutorial can be found here:
• Basic Math Block
• Circle Block
• Color Block
• Common Constants Block
• Count Block
• Cylinder Block
• If, Then Statement Block
• Logic Compare Block
• Mirror Block
• Module Block
• Number Block
• Random Integer Block
• Rotate Block
• Set Variable Block
• Sides Block
• Test: If True, If False Block
• To Module Block
• Translate Block
• True/False Block
• Union Block
• Variable Block

As a volunteer who regularly helps with the BEST Robotics Competition (Boosting, Engineering, Science, and Technology), I see just how valuable sofware like BlocksCAD can be in helping students create 3D designs while also learning fundamentals of programming. It excites me that as a result of this competitions three schools throughout the nation will get a free 2 year subscrition to BlocksCAD®. It is my hope that regardless the outcome of the competition, this tutorial can be used in aiding students in learning BlocksCAD®. For this reason, I authorize the reuse, modification, or recreation of this tutorial and its contents within the educational setting.

I hope you enjoy! Please post some of your created snowflakes under the makes tab on this thing.

title: Gear and motor box for Gauge G (IIm) and Gauge 1
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Gear and motor box are configurable in transmission ratio and mounting options.

The project is demonstrated for the Stephenson locomotive published here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:564002

The motor is a very tiny 12V motor with 200rpm. You can get it at also for different voltages and rpm.

The gear presented here reduces the rpm again by 1:2.
I choosed the 12V Version of this motor because a want to run the locomotive with current slider contacts on the standard LGB rails. Currently the locomotive runs with a 9V accumulator.

I used this motor: https://www.amazon.de/dp/B071PFDBD7/_encoding=UTF8?coliid=I351Z49K02X4M3&colid=1L98TO5ZF8GFI&th=1

Version 2 released: Motor box modified to encapsulate the gear of the motor. The last two pictures show the Version 2 mounted and the parts.

Version 3.1 released. See extra section below.

You can find here a matching current pickup, the spring and the spring box https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2783406

A special current pickup for Playmobil locomotives is here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2767624

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.1 mm

1) File off any burrs before fixing the gear box. The planes on which the box will be mounted
must be absolutely even and orthognal to the axle(s).
Minimal corrections can also be done by putting under a piece of paper or plastic before screwing all together.

The gear behaviour is very sensitive to distance and angle difference offset.
When compiling the OpenSCAD file the distancies are printed in the console window.

The gear pair is mounted correctly, when the noise reaches a minimum.

2) Instead of set screws bore a 1mm hole through the prepared holes and the axles,
insert a 1mm wire and bend them by 90°.

3) Do step 2 also for the already existing wheels of your models. By this you get a little
mechanical clearance at the wheels.
Because most models have no differential gear, you get a better behaviour in narrow curves.

4) Since version 3.1 you can select expicitely horizontal mounting. In this case the fixing wings are
always printed. The wings have a fixed size which is calculated from the mechanical parameters
defined in the *.scad file. The wings are printed on both sides of the box, so you can mount the
box in front or behind the motor. Four holes for the screws are printed in both wings (diameter 1mm). You have to bore up the holes for your needs. On the non-to-fix-side you have to bore up the holes to a size, that your screw driver can pass them.

Miscellaneous

When pulling more than two Playmobil or LGB coaches, the gear wheels may skip by one or two tooths,
because the motor (and its box) is fixed only one side (and at the opposite side of the gears).
Advantage: Motor will not block if overstressed.

You can avoid this behaviour by pushing together the gear wheels a liitle bit. Yet if you
push them together too much the motor may be blocked and / or noise increases. This may also damage the tooths.

For the Stephenson locomotive I decided (for me) to cut 1,8mm of the axle carrier. Marked in red
Otherwise I had to choose another transmission ratio or choose manually another circular pitch.

Example for the console output of OpenSCAD if the box will not fit:
ECHO:
ECHO: "Circular Pitch:", 159.545
ECHO: "Axle No of Teeths:", 20, "Pitch Radius:", 8.86364, "Root Radius:", 7.77727, "Outer Radius:", 9.75
ECHO: "Motor No of Teeths", 10, "Pitch Radius:", 4.43182, "Root Radius:", 3.34545, " Outer Radius:", 5.31818
ECHO:
ECHO: "Distance between gears axles:", 13.2955
ECHO: "Free space left to the AxleFirstFreeMountingPosition:", -1.70455
ECHO: "Note: Minimum distance must be: ", 15
ECHO: "Increase number of teeths for the motor or decrease (mechanical) AxleFirstFreeMountingPosition"
ECHO: "Gear box dimensions (Length x Width x Height:", 18, 16, 30.4455
ECHO:

Most of the parameters for the gear and the gear box can be selected in the .scad file.
For users without OpenScad experience open the file with a text editor.
The .scad file is decorated with a lot of comments about the different parameters
and contains also tips about the 'what and how to do'.
Different parameters like available physical dimensions, free space available, transmission ratio
and much more is selectable.

Enhancements to Version 2

1) Selectable fixing plate. Enhances stability and needs no modifications of the model.
2) Introducing a backlash value. Reduces abrasion and noise
3) The gear pair and the gear box are calculated from the parameters.
4) Messages are output for the radii of the gears and the size of the gear box.
A warning is output if the gear box will not match without modifying the model.
5) In Version 3.1 you can select horizontal mounting explicitly.

Outlook to the future: I will split the parts with the physical dimensions of the model to a
separate file, which will be included at compile time.

But now i will really concentrate the work on the current pickups....

I have a set of Tiki Torches in the backyard that have the container for torch oil with a wick. Sometimes a pain in the butt to keep full of oil.
I saw the LED flame bulbs advertised and bought a set, but I wanted to use them in the existing torches since they are sturdy steel.
I designed the bottom section to snap into the existing metal torch, with a hole for a tight fit of a outdoor socket.
A translucent sleeve fits on the bottom section over the bulb, and then the top section snaps onto the top ring of the torch and over the sleeve.
Just thought I would share this as the finished product turned out well.

This is a Z-axis endstop relocation mount for the Tristarbot M1 Printer. I created this mount when we upgraded the hot end to a Prusa housing for the E3D V6.

This mount will allow you to mount the endstop switch for the z-axis lower than the factory settings. This comes in handy with different hot end setups as they are shorter than the factory hot end for this printer.

I made the part with slots for the end-stop mount holes to allow you to move it in and out so it can be properly adjusted.

I printed the mount out of Nylon with a .15 layer height with 25% infill for rigidity. But realistically it could be printed with different settings. Id recommend not using PLA due to its fragile nature, and this needing to hold the switch in place so it can be pressed.

To mount the bracket, you will need an extra 3mm screw and square nut for the frame. I matched up the one that it came with for the factory mount.

description.text:
I've created this case to make the CR10 portable with the a mounting plate for RAMPS, the original CR10 MOSFET, the RaspberryPi and the CR10 power supply and a mounting plate for the Melzi (including the CR10S board), original CR10 MOSFET, the RaspberryPi and the CR10 power supply.

Screws needed:
15x (or 17x) M4x10 (6 for the electric case, 6 for the power supply case, 1 for the power switch feet & 2 or 4 for the display depending on wich you are printing)
16x M4x40 (for the Squashball feet, you can use tho old T-Nuts - hammer nuts)
13x M4 T-Nuts (Hammer Nuts)
4x M3x5 - maybe M3x10 work also (for the power supply)
1x M3x10 (for the screw to connect the two cases together at the front)
4x M4x40 (for the 140mm fan)
2x Metal screws for the power switch
Metal screws for the PI, MOSFET and the Board you are using
(4x M3x10 for the display depending on wich you are printing)
(if you use the cable guides you also need 1x M4x10 and 1x M4 T-Nut - hammer nut for one guide)

With this case you don't cool the heated bed, air exhausts only to the side and back.

What you'll also need is 4 Squashballs (2 yellow dots), a power supply inlet with switch and fuse, a few zip ties and a 140mm FAN (if you want you can also a fan grill).

Don't forget to create support for the power inlet feet, LCD mount and the cable guids.

Edit3: Corrected 4th mounting hole for MKS Gen Case
Edit2: Few modifications for the fan mount/support and a new display mount at the front left side
Edit1: Added cases for boards MKS Gen and MKS Robin

title: Modified X carriage for Hypercube using carbon fiber X axis and RJMP-01-08 plastic linear bearings

description.text: If you want to use carbon fiber rods for Hypercube X axis, you need to use plastic bearings and thus modify the X-carriage. I used the widely available RJMP-01-08 bearings They are about $1.50 apiece. I modified some of the dimensional parameters to fit the larger bearings. It also needs a looser fit than steel since a tight fit deforms the bearing, so I had to also add 4 circular guides that will snap the bearings into place and will hold them securely.

author: WondrousDrones

title: sprung landing gear, front wheel assembly for skyhunter

description.text:
Hi,
take a look at my other designs https://www.thingiverse.com/mg_evolution/designs

This is still a work in progress and is not finished.

I have designed this for my Micro Skyhunter.

Fitted to the plane : https://youtu.be/otwbvkb_XnM

Table top test : https://youtu.be/cGbfdJWHNn4

I want to make this take off and land on wheels so it doesn't have to be thrown and it doesn't break the prop as i land.

The spring used in this is 20mm long x 5mm dia. it is relativly soft and will more than likely bottom out on landing but it has not yet been tried.

The front wheel is printed in 2 halfs that are a mirror image. The 2 bolt holes are there to line up the wheels when gluing them together. I used gorilla glue and haven't cleaned it up for the pictures.

As i have it pictured with the long bolts it's weight is 8g. with the suspension fully compressed on a set of scales I am reading 550g. This can be changed by using a stiffer spring or by extending the pivot point further out away from the wheel.
The landing gear is secured through to the inside with a 10mm long self taper suitable for the 3mm hole. The inside support has a 8mm wide square to sit in the cut out of the balsa wood insert in the plane.

I printed the wheels with 2 walls and 8% zigzag infill in cura.
The frame was printed with 2 wall with alternative wall set on and 15% zigzag infill in cura

All pivot holes are suitable for M3 bolts. Nylocs should be used to stop vibration loosening fixings.

title: Tevo Little Monster linear rail upgrade parts

description.text:
These parts are for the conversion of the pulley's on a Tevo Little Monster into linear rails. After the conversion it will become much quieter and way more accurate.
Update: 3/8/2018, Rod spacing update
Note: TLM carriage is 45mm, while M4 slide carriages are 40mm across
You need either to shim the linear rail shuttles to match 45mm width or print your own
Update: 2/5/2018, reinforced endstop belt tab
Update: 1/21/2018, updated the trigger flange for a better fit
You must print this in ABS since PLA is transparent to the optical endstop LED frequency You could also just tape over the trigger flange if you must print it in PLA.

These parts are for a Tevo Little Monster linear rail upgrade. It includes rail alignment positioners and a plate that triggers the optical endstops along with a belt loop for the flying extruder. You will need 3 of the rail aligners and 3 of the endstop plates.

The endstop plates work fine on all the 20mm * 20mm mini-Kossel shuttles that i've tested and allow you to keep the default factory position for the optical endstops. This allows you to back out the linear rail upgrade to factory in short order.

I provide both the STL and Openscad files so you can customize it if necessary.
I have a series of Youtube video's showing the conversion (Part #1 is here): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jfg3GfMekQ0

title: Triple Servo Tester
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I'm currently building several walking robots, all powered by servos. The problem then arises in working out the extent of motion with each one and also the range of motion available. I have several dumb testers, but needed one that displayed the actual arduino servo position number, from 1-180. This means I can manually adjust and take down the values. An arduino, 3 pots, some pins an SPI OLED and a JST is required along with a cheap power converter to ensure that it all runs at 5v.
I initially started out with a plain box, but then thought "What would Adam Savage do?" and so added some design details, sprayed it in primer and with various inks and weathering powders gave it a used look.
I also made some nicks and cuts and painted them silver to give the impression of a metal box and painted and dirtied up the knobs. A glass cabochon was used as screen bezel.

code available : https://www.instructables.com/id/Arduino-Triple-Servo-Tester/

comments.text:
Collected and liked for both the usefulness and the fact that you asked yourself "What would Adam Savage do?" in it's design. Plus it's very nicely labeled робот (robot in russian for those non-multi-linguists) which just adds that extra touch.
This is functional art and awesomeness!

title: Mini Commodore C64 with space for Wemos D1 mini ESP8266 microcontroller
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
What is this?

A remixed base for the Mini Commodore C64 by RabbitEngineering with space for a Wemos D1 Mini ESP8266 micrcontroller.

Upload what you want to the ESP but I'd recommend a C64 emulator for full retro geekery https://github.com/NardJ/esp8266-C64

How to use

Just print the parts from the original design files and this lower instead of the lower body. Pop a Wemos D1 mini in the space and assemble as in the original.

description.text: Futuristic storage containers for all your storage needs.
Small storage drums scatter terrain.

Walking through a Dollar Tree store, I spotted these pre-cut double-sided sticky tape rolls for $1. So I came up with a drawing. You can buy self adhesive zip tie mounts for $7 - 100 pieces, but save a few cents by making your own. The mount measures roughly 1/2" (12.7mm) x 3/4" (19.05mm) x .150" (3.81mm) tall. I made the width of the openings (.220") large enough that 3/16" wide zip-ties can fit though easily.

Printer:

Cr-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

100%

This is a fun little design I've perfect over several iterations. Print with supports. I think PLA works best. For some reason the files saved with the propeller angled sideways. make sure to position the file so that the central hole is pointing up and the entire length of the propeller is touching the bed (it'll only do this in one position). After printing, glue a chopstick into the central hole of the propeller with hot glue or something else. All chopsticks are made differently so you might not find one that fits just right. The file "Propeller 4" is the most updated version and works the best. Once you have the chopstick in, spin it between your hands and let it fly!

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

description.text: This is a plate designed to fill the gap left in the front of a Nerf AirtTech 2000 when modified. It is very common with these blasters to remove the stock turret and install a coupler / single barrel for a dramatic increase in range. This plate is designed to allow 1/2 inch pvc pipe to pass through and into a 1/2 inch pvc coupler glued to the air tank. Please not it will most likely require light sanding to get your pvc so slide through it smoothly.

comments.author: DonStick3l

comments.text: How did everyone print this? Are you using dual extruders with a support filament? I've never had any luck with Simplify3d's support generation.
comments.author: PowerScissor

comments.text: No dual extruders here. Simply breakaway support structures. Personally I like to use Support Interfaces. Generates a solid barrier between the actual support pattern and the model's surface leaving two layer heights gap. This way the bottom of the model comes out perfect but is easy to separate from the interface (most of the time).
comments.author: PowerScissor

comments.text: The limbs. I figured I'd start with what appeared to be the most difficult to print first that way I don't waste a bunch of printing only to find I can't make the final piece.
comments.author: DonStick3l

comments.text:
By gap you mean in z-direction between the layers? Because the support generation is supposed to leave one or two layers gap (see screenshot). This way it is easier to remove later on. But as soon as the support is printed after the skipped layers it should stick to the top of the model nevertheless. When producing spaghetti, something else has to be messed up.
Lowering the gap distance to zero will most certainly give you fused model and support. And I don't expect it to be easy nor clean to remove, even by machining with a dremel.
comments.author: PowerScissor

comments.text: Would you be willing to upload the files after exporting them from Fusion360 to Sketchup format? comments.text: Just converted and uploaded every individual part in Collada (.dae) as well as a Blender file with a collection of everything.
comments.author: PowerScissor

comments.text: Thanks, I'll get this thing printed at some point...lol.  Just a curiosity, is there a purpose besides weight, to have the wheels with "spokes"? I was getting very brittle results, and was going to make them solid...wasn't sure if there was a function the particular shape or not though.
comments.author: DonStick3l

comments.text:
Legitimate question. No the skeletonized structure of idler wheel and cam serves no specific purpose in this scale. Of course on a life size bow you would want to cut down on weight. Especially for moving parts as mass comes with inertia and negative impact on the performance.
On a model that small the components in question could simply be made solid. Would be much easier in fact.
I just wanted to keep as much of an original bow's look and feel as possible. And skeletonized always looks damn tactical to me!

description.text:
Hi,
take a look at my other designs https://www.thingiverse.com/mg_evolution/designs

This is a work in progress and not tested

I made this for my Micro Skyhunter plane to go with the front landing gear i have designed.

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2764934

This is attached to the rear of the plane by putting the wing bolts through the sliders before attaching to the fuselage.
The legs attachment to each other allow for a bit of gap sizing.This makes the wheels closer or further apart by around 10mm. Breaking the end will allow the slider to open to a larger gap.

It makes the wing sit 2mm higher off the fuselage.

It doesn't look the nicest but hopefully it should be practical.

The legs have been printed with 3 walls and 15% zigzag infill in cura.
The wheels have been printed with 2 walls and 8% zigzag infill in cura.

I may well redisign the wheels to look more like round rubber tyres.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/8mPC6Fe17ea

title: Replicator 2 Plate Holder (4 Point Leveling)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Update
You may need thing:2767970 if your build plate is at least 8mm thick

I wanted a bigger build volume for my CTC Replicator, and decided to get the Replicator 2 build plate from Makerbot. I went with this option because I personally have had a great experience with how level and uniform this build surface is. Also, I print directly on the build plate with a glue stick and it works every time.This is designed to allow build surface removal, but only for PLA printing as this is a non-heated build plate. I printed this in PLA at 190C, and its plenty strong enough to keep form with frequent plate removal. But its also springy enough to pull the back tab and pull the plate out.

I suppose you could use a different build plate with this adapter, but it was designed specifically for the Rep 2 build plate. If you have a Replicator 2, this might be a good way to implement a 4 - point leveling system.

I am using shorter springs than stock for the front two of the leveling system. I believe this is because the plastic arms are slightly warped upwards so the back and front of the plate need to be leveled at different heights.

Printer:

CTC Replicator Dual

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25%

Notes:

I printed this in PLA at 190C

You may need a raft if experiencing warping.

supports are recommended because of the recessed areas on the bottom for the springs.

title: Wanhao i3 Rear Filament Feed Guide

description.text: Due to a reconfiguration of my workshop, I had to locate my filament spool "behind" my Wanhao i3 (i.e. next to the Y axis motor), and feed the filament over the drag chain and into the extruder from the rear, so to speak. This caused the filament to rub across the drag chain and wires, which wasn't desirable. This mod, which attaches using two M3 screws through the drag-chain mounting points, alleviates that rubbing.

Printer:

Wanhao i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

If you haven't improved your cooling options (I haven't), the ring can be problematic - the layers are small enough that the previous layer may not have cooled by the time the next layer starts. Better cooling or increased minimum layer time may help this.

This mod requires some additional hardware:

  • 2 @ M3 machine screws, at least 12mm
  • 2 @ M3 nuts (lock nuts or lock washers optional).

Replace the two pan-head M3 screws that hold the drag chain to the extruder with two longer M3 screws (at least 10mm). These will thread into the existing drag-chain mounting holes. Place the filament guide holes over the screws, and secure with two M3 nuts.

You will note that the side of the filament guide that sits next to the extruder is recessed to accommodate the threaded holes in the mounting plate. Thus, this part should sit flush to the rear of the drag-chain attachment plate, which keeps it square and stable.
Designed in Fusion360 using measurements taken directly from the Wanhao i3. First revision had the ring in the same plane as the mount, but this still left the filament rubbing on the extruder wires.

description.text:
The RF2000 is a great printer, but the holes in the extruder are too big, so that the filament can jump of the bearing. This part fixes this issue.

BTW, it's a filament guide, but the file's are called filament cleaner, because the idea was that you can insert a piece of foam material, so that you can clean the filament from dust.
So far I didn't try this.

Printer:

RF2000

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Notes:

Tip: I printed four parts at a time, just to give these small parts more time for cooling, before printing the next layer.

Fill the tube with pills and dispense them one at a time with every full rotation.

Assemble the pieces based on the photos. You will need a metal pin for the center post and also a metal pin to attach the bracket at the bottom. For the lower pin, I used 14 gauge copper wire. The metal pin is from a printer disassembly or something and it is 4.76mm diameter.

The small recessed holes are for magnets. I was going to use them to kinda lock in the various positions, but I was not impressed, so you can ignore them.

--
I have to take just one dumb pill every day. Trying to come up with creative ways to dispense.

Dumb Monday-Sunday pill minder does a pretty good job but lacks pizzazzzz!

The pill represents the pill I want to dispense

This is my participation for the #BlocksCADSnowflake.

I never used BlocksCAD3D, it's my first time with this kind of 3d software, but i enjoyed using it.
As a student and son of teacher, I already used blocks developpement tools like Scratch to teach the basics of the programmation and i think that a such approach of the 3d modeling can be very usefull.
When i was in highschool (french) they teach us how to use software like SolidWorks, but a such software is too complex and too hard to use for beginners students and a lot of people get lost on this software, i think if we used somethings like BlockCad3D it will be a way more usefull for us.

As a reference i used this macro photography of a snowflakes, i tried to reproduce the maximum of this snowflake, and in the same time, using the maximum of mathematical possibilty of BlocksCad3d software.

Here my project : https://www.blockscad3d.com/community/projects/72211

I haven't print this (any 3d printer yet) but you can scale it down of course, but keep a sensible infill.

Macro Photography : Alexey Kljatov

title: Marlin Firmware 1.1.8 Anycubic Kossel Plus - G33 "auto_calibrate" Updated

description.text:
This added file is a mix of the Marlin Firmware for the Anycubic Kossel Plus, and added modifications from the firmware of FLSUN kossel.

Anycubic not update the editable firmware, and in need levelling the printer correctly.

The more important step in this firmware is read the point "08. G29 Auto bed leveling", not use auto level M29 system, this firmware work whit M33 "auto_calibrate" and work for me fine, the level of the bed is simply perfect.

Is important for the auto calibrate make the steps in the point of the next link, the step "02" and "07", in the step "02" go to sub step "5. Run the G33 command" - "6. Set your Z-offset" and "7. Send M500 to save calibration from RAM to EEPROM"
https://github.com/FLSun3dp/FLSun-Kossel-Mini/wiki/02.-Calibrate-your-printer

Simple and perfect for me, i not test the procedure in the screen, all the process i make from Printrun, is important use all the explained procedure in the marked steps from the link added.

In the images appear the z prove i use.

I level the printer with z-prove in the effector, the offset is -0,1mm.
I add calibration spiral, scale for print.

Atention: my firmware have modified for me, is important edit and define the printer options, DELTA_HEIGHT and DELTA_DIAGONAL_ROD. Attention the motor directions for my TMC2100 drivers are inverse, please modify for your printer firmware and your drivers.

The marlin language is set to spanish, change it.

!!!! after install the firmware is important reset in the panel the EEPROM !!!!

I update the firmware with low speeds 25 january

!!!! After flashing the firmware do not forget to send the commands M502 and M500.

The process to auto calibrate is simply in various steps:

In printrun send the commands and wait finish:

G33 P1
(wait the auto calibrate)
G33 P2
(wait the auto calibrate)
G33 P5
(wait the auto calibrate)
G33 P10
(wait the auto calibrate)
G28
(HOME)
M851 Z0.0
(set offset Z to 0)
G90
(absolute positioning)

G1 Z1 - etc etc
(Start manually the "paper test" and obtain the correct Z offset, use it in the next command)
M851 Z0.xx
(Set your Z offset)
M500
(Save the correct configuration)

Test the calibration with the spiral - Perfect ; )

// Invert the stepper direction. Change (or reverse the motor connector) if an axis goes the wrong way. !!! Modificado para TMC2100 !!!

define INVERT_X_DIR false // DELTA does not invert

define INVERT_Y_DIR false

title: cr-10 control box base plate & legs for dual 120mm fans
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
a fan base for the cr-10 control box. this piece replaces the original base plate. it screws into the control box with the original screws, the legs attach when screwing in the fans.

the legs are suprisingly solid when filled completely and the holes allow the original feet to be screwed in.

I use two fans in a push-pull configuration. I had two different fans lying around and put the stronger one in the front pushing in, (tested by putting a flimsy trash bag over the base with fans running).

ghetto airflow analysis with some incense shows some exhaust air looping around to the input, the vanes help but haven't completely resolved that issue

the listed remix items were used for inspiration and measurements, but the actual model is designed completely from scratch in tinkercad.

changelog

0.2.0 (untested)

replaced honeycomb grill

  • reduced honeycomb supports to 2mm
0.1.2 (untested)

remade the front/back face

  • increased side walls to 1mm for stabillity (and removed sloping)
  • added 45° angled bottoms to overhangs similar to curas 'make overhangs printable'
  • increased middle screw cutout to 10mm wide (my dingus didnt fit)
0.1.0

original release

Printer:

creality cr-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.4

Infill:

legs 100%, plate doesent matter

Notes:

I used PLA for everything, all pieces can be squeezed onto the bed when plate adhesion (brim / skirt) is turned off, but i havent tried printing this becasue the legs might detach without a brim. (and i designed the pieces one after the other)

base:
0.4mm layers
no brim / skirt
no supports ( I may have used curas "make printable" feature to get the screw holes slightly conical, I dont remember)
any infill ( 20% triangles? something like that)

legs:
0.4mm layers
brim for better adhesion
support (I used concentric at 1% with 5mm xy distance to support only the floating legs but not the honey comb holes)

exhaust vanes: (experimental)
0.2mm layers (0.4 not tested, the part that slides under the legs is very thin)
skirt ( a brim might break it)
no supports needed

assembly
  1. attach the original feet to the legs
  2. add two fans to the base plate
  3. (optional) add the exhaust vanes to the rear side
  4. screw the fans in with the 4 holes at the center of the plate
  5. add the legs to the front and rear and screw them to the fans through the base plate
    some fans dont work with self-tapping screws, i used m4 screws with nuts for the front (pulling) fan because of this.
  6. attach the control box. with the original 5 machine screws
    be careful, as the plastic is pretty thin and cracks easily

*** blood sweat and tinkercad tears ***

many parts went through several iterations before they sliced right, but once cura was happy it worked well. one corner curled up during printing, but a heat gun and a lot of cursing got the fan to fit.

the base plate is made of boxes surrounded by very slim wedges and quarter-pyramids for the corners. the screw holes are half cylinders with boxes in between.

the front was originally one solid wedge, but to reduce infill the wedges were reduced to were the screwholes are and the front is just a box. this was a real pain before I knew tinkercads "workplane" feature

detail of combined pieces for the base plate front and sides *** not a fan: hexagons, airflow and structural integrity ***

looking for grills i got hung up on "honeycomb" patterns and tinkercad had multiple tiled hexagon (or polygon) shape generators.
the biggest problem was fitting the hexagons to the (modeled) 120mm fan. after multiple failures i found a combination of radius, spacing and offset that was only slightly imbalanced, and put the thicker connections lengthwise.

to have space for screw holes (and because they were outside the fans diameter) the corner hexagons were manually cut out before inverting the hexagons into holes.

(the transparent yellow squares were just a placeholder for the 120x25mm fans)

hexagon fan grilles and fan mounting holes *** the tipping point: legs, feet and stabillity ***

the legs went through several ideas and revisions. I liked the open "beam" leg design by summerside guy https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2659909 , but didnt want to mix curved legs with a straight / polygonal baseplate.
Also i wasnt sure how stable and strong such an open design would be. Thankfully they have been super solid.

for the actual design i built a paralelogram (wedge - box - inverted wedge ) and cut out a cross from the center by duplicating and scaling them. the top plate shares its holes with the base plate.

the feet are boxes with quarter pyramids that are clipped (and scaled) to stay within the surrounding wedges.

legs and feet taking shape (left to right). some cutout polygons are slightly oversized because the sloped faces left a super thin plane after combining *** rebreathing: airflow issues and exhaust vanes (experimental) ***

this design helps, but does not completely solve air-recycling issures, to be improved

originally I had a piece of ducttape to seperate the front intake and rear exhaust, but after seeing a youtube video using incense to analyze airflow i realized the exhaust air went all the way to the floor and back to the intake, so I needed to redirect the exhaust far away from the intake.

I had a polygonal duct in mind (more wedges and pyramids, yay) but the output area was less than half of the fans area and reading about corners, bends and turning vanes (little redirection fins to reduce turbulence) I realized something round would be needed.

The model is quite simple, a cut of plate with screw & fan holes and 3 hollow half cylinders, cut to 45° wedges, stacked and clipped so they clear the legs.

I didnt want to have 3 parts between the rear screws and the fan, so I left some super thin tabs to slide under the rear legs.

title: Slim Rostock Max v3 Fan for 713Maker Mounts

description.text: After upgrading to the 713Maker mount (http://713maker.com/mounts.html) for my E3Dv6, I found that the original slim fan shroud was too small. I remixed Noircogi's design to be both longer so it'll reach the print area, and added a gap in the middle of it to allow the PCB to sit in the gap. This results in a taller fan duct, and kind of works with autoleveling if you get them on straight and do a good job wiring. This is a WIP, as I would have brought the exhaust down lower but I didn't want to have to cut the tabs off of the effector - something which may eventually be required.

author: Horvaticus

description.text:
Printed to replace a broken clip on the adjustable shower head. Could not find anything like it on here already, and suspect that it will never be printed by something but figure if I needed it, maybe one day someone else will.

Turn it sideways so the spring hole is facing up, print with base supports only.

It's an universal screw clamp, made out of 4 different parts to be printed out plus a M4 screw and nut. Idea Basically i wanted to have some kind of "universal screw clamp" as a reference design, because i love to do all sorts of handywork and crafting. Sometimes when you glue stuff together you just don't have the right tool to hold everything in place while you wait for the glue to bond properly. so, this is my solution to this problem. I'm really looking forward to develop this idea later on and make it even better and more universal. :) Function
  • There is an U-shaped main part that serves as the basic structure.
  • In the top of this u-shape is a standard M4 nut that gets glued in so it does not fall out. (a snug fit should hold it in there too)
  • Into the M4 nut we screw a long enough M4 bolt, with the head of the screw pointing away from the u-shape.
  • Onto the head of the screw we mount a handle, so we don't need any tools to tighten up the clamp.
  • On the bottom of the screw there is a ball joint made out of two extruded parts with the ball beeing attached to the M4 screw.
    This should help to clamp uneven stuff together and prevent the screw from trying to twist the clamped parts.
    This ball joint is really highly experimental. I have no idea how good it will work with extruded parts and if i can even get the ball inside the ball cage. It\'s made to be able to snap in there, but i have no idea if that works in reality with ABS parts...
    • Aditional info
    This is actually my first design for an extruded part and i don't have my Makerbot yet to test the geometry, tolerances and stability of everything, so take this as a alpha-version or preview that has not been tested yet! The original design was made on SolidWorks. I still have an old license from the time i was studying microtechnics. It's the CAD tool i am used to and i could not find any open source tool with similar gui yet. Important for every SolidWorks user: If you have problems with the STL files (Skeinforge crashing) try to import and export them with Blender. Somehow the STL format that SolidWorks saves in is not the same as Blender exports to... Comments are always welcome, and as soon as i have my CupCake up and running you can expect some updates and hopefully even a printed version that works

Well, i guess most of it has been said in the description.
If you have questions, want me to get rid of all the roundings and fine details, or have other ideas or sugestions, feel free to add your comment.
Thanks, and E N J O Y ! :o)

comments.text: I mostly use solidworks to make objects to be printed to and have the same problem. Skeinforge doesn't see any STL's exported by solidworks but after importing and exporting from blender the problem goes away. I'm not sure why that happens.
comments.author: mechamithrandir

comments.text: I think Solidworks saves some extra information into the STL file. Have you ever tryed to reopen an STL that works with Skeinforge? It seems to have another surface that swallows up all the light. If you open a SW saved STL you can still use scene lights to get a better view of your part. So my guess is that SW has some kind of extra surface property saved into the STL, and Skeinforge can't handle that part.

title: Field Stand for Metal Detector (e.g. Bounty Hunter LR Pro)

description.text:
The design is currently under real world test ...
Please be aware of the license: CC - Attribution - Non-Commercial

This is a basic one leg stand for a metal detector like the Bounty Hunter LR Pro.
It's designed to keep the detector out of the mud while digging in a wet field.
As rod, use a 20mm dark grey high pressure PVC pipe. It should be cut to the length where the inserted magnet in the tip can reach some metal to be locked to the handle while searching.
Insert a 8mm Neodyn magnet in the tip and glue it. Add a small piece of metal to your detector handle to keep the leg fixed in place.

Update;
Two alternative tips are added.

Handling:
When starting to search, fix the leg with the magnet to your handle. When you have to put your detector away, loose the leg. It will point down. Push it into the wet earth.
When you pick up your detector, push the leg forward until it is fixed to the handle by the magnet again.

Real world pictures will follow.

Additional requirements:
2 M3x14 screw + nut
1 M3x30 screw + nut

Fill holes in the tip and the PipeMount with epoxy to enhance stability if required (e.g. printing with PLA)

Add On:
If it's not completely fixed to your handle, add a small bit of e.g. Neoprene between the handle and the bottom and top mounts-

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

[email protected]

Notes:

at least 1mm solid bottom and top layer
Keep infill high to ensure mechanical stability.

title: MP Select Mini Modified Fan Holder

description.text:
I have the Monoprice Select Mini V1. It is my first ever printer and I have owned it for four weeks. I read that you should try to limit the cooling when printing ABS so I have been using masking tape. I have modeled this fan shroud so that I can slide on different nozzles. While I was at it, I thought it might be handy if I could do away with the need for the screws holding the fan in place.
As I am still very new to this, I would love to have some input from more experienced printers as I am unsure about how effective the cooling and lack of it is.
NB I did have to sand the nozzle parts very slightly to get a good fit.
I used ABS from Rigid Ink my printer seems to like this stuff.

description.text:
This brain was extracted from the Visible Human data set. The tissue was masked from slice photographs, and the resulting volume was trimmed and sculpted for 3D printing. This is the top portion of the brain, with the bottom flattened so it will print well.

Visible Human_Brain Top_Glow - This version is designed to be illuminated internally (a common request). It has a hollow space inside with roughly 45 degree walls, and a channel on the back for a wire. With sparse fill this double-layer model should provide good diffusion for an LED ring or other light.

Brain Shell 1.6mm - This is a similar design with a thickness of exactly 1.6mm to match the common 0.4mm extrusion nozzles on many printers. It had originally been hollowed to 1.5mm for nylon printing, and has been scaled up by an additional 6.667 percent. You can add generated support with this one, then remove it for a totally hollow brain. Requires a large format printer at this scale.

Visible Human Brain_Whole - The brain without the bottom flattened. Needs support for printing.

Notes:

The "glow" version has enough surface to print without a brim or support. The hollow version should use both.

author: CosmoDuck

title: Archon W38vr Diving Video light mount replacement

description.text:
The orignial ring mount for the archon Archon W38vr is a crappy made. The ball mount is connected with two small screws with are too tiny for the levering forces of the lamp and the arms of the video light. I created a new and better version for the original ball mount.

Tip: use M4 2mm RVS bolds and nuts for the top tightening and M3 2mm bolds for the connection with the ball mount. The 2mm is a little bid too large so use an extra nut on top (see photo).

Everything is a really tight fit. You have to squeeze the nuts and the mount in their sockets. Remove the 0-rings before you slide it on the lamp!! Otherwise you will destroy them (as did I).

Printed on 60% infill and with no support

remixed_from.author: darkytoothpaste
remixed_from.title: CR-10 flexible filament extruder bracket with adjustable spring tension

description.text:
This Thing was inspired by trying to find a thrifty way to print flexible filament on My friends CR10s. I began with the CR-10 flexible Filament Extruder by darkytoothpaste ( , CR-10 flexible filament extruder bracket with adjustable spring tension found on #Thingiverse https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2604471) then I found s_gutz's direct drive bracket ( CR-10 Direct Drive found on #Thingiverse https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2735674 ) and said...wtf? I dropped them into s3d, lined up the holes and let it rip. I plan to mount it behind my OEM Fang.
NOTE
As with the direct drive bracket alone It did cost 30mm of build space on the X axis. My stepper motor would hit the right-hand Gantry support so I altered the bed size in firmware, how you do it is up to you but be advised that you may need to make an adjustment somewhere.

Hope it works for someone. I'll be mounting it up tonight.

Creality CR-10

Doesn't Matter

.2mm

96

Notes:

I used Robo PLA in red, 220/60 100% feed rate If it works I'll do it in ABS low and slow.

Version
1.0. Initial concept release
HUGE CAVEAT The .STL file I had originally published Doesn't work!! Get the G-Code file for V-1.1 .

      *Small caveat, The chamfered screw hole at the top of the bracket that goes into the stepper motor didn't get chamfered, so you'll have to either fix the file, which I might get to, or use a countersink bit and take care of it.*

1.1.
01/24/2018

       *Fixed the Screw hole issue in makerbot but could not export a decent .stl file that would print so I mashed some more together in Simplify3d and exported the G-Code.
          *

title: Ultimaker Reel Holder V3: 32mm Reel Diameter

description.text:
This is a derivative of ConcreteTurtle's reel holder, which is a derivative LawrenceJohnson's reel holder, designed to fit wider and even smaller diameter PLA reels (92mm wide x 32mm ID). Motivated by a spool that I bought on Amazon (listed as Jet - PLA (3mm, Orange color, 1.0kg =2.204lbs) Filament on Spool for 3D Printer MakerBot, RepRap, MakerGear, Ultimaker and UP!)  that had a small diameter bore. 
Note: reducing the reel_radius parameter in the SCAD file below 32/2 caused OpenSCAD to crash on rendering, so this is the smallest reel radius possible without redesigning the assembly.

1) Print two arms, one holder, and one end. I used Cura 12.07 default parameters when I printered ConcreteTurtle's 37mm reel version.
2) Place arms in bracket on back of Ultimaker.
3) Place holder on arms with larger radius section in notches nearest the back of the Ultimaker.
4) Place reel on holder.
5) Place end piece in notches at end of arms.
When I print this piece and confirm everything works, I'll put up a picture of the new assembly...

description.text:
Get ready for yet another First World Problem. This is a minimalist tool to prevent tea from leaking out of one's cup through the teabag wire due to capillary action, which may happen if you simply let the wire hang over the edge of the cup.
If you correctly make a customized model and print it correctly, then the wire should be well clamped in one of the gaps. If not, you can still try wrapping it through both of the gaps for extra grip.

The example model is for a spoon with a handle 10 mm wide and at most 2.1 mm thick. Use Customizer to make a model that fits your favorite spoon(s).
If Customizer is broken on the Thingiverse website, here are instructions to run it on your own computer.

This is best printed in a flexible filament, because it reduces the need for a perfectly accurate print, and allows the Tea Helper to easily fit non-straight handles.

title: Expandable shelving
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Expandable and 3D printable racking.
Updates at the bottom... Latest update 1/22/18
Yes, I'll make more updates and add-on accessories to this design. Please feel free to comment on what you would like to see with this.

The pictures shown is the first section I've built and me testing it with a few full boxes of filament. (No issues holding that up)
I left the corner locks long so you can see where they go. Yes, they are a tight fit.

The concept is very similar to the wire racking you get at the hardware store.
You have uprights with little grooves in them, a lock that goes into the groove and a sleeve that goes over it to lock it in place at a certain height.

Since it would be difficult to print wire racking, I broke this down into smaller trusses that interlock to form a shelf.

To start, you will need to print the following.
4 uprights - about an hour each.
4 locking rings - Couple minutes
4 corner pieces - about an hour each
2 main trusses - about an hour each
2 main trusses without the cross piece - also about an hour each
4 7-inch crossing trusses - about 30 minutes each.
You will also need the locking pin to keep the main trusses in place, I like the version you can cut since it's easier to work with.
Top Plate - Haven't tested the fit yet, but it's sized to fit on top between the corner pieces. It's a little over 7"x7". If your printer isn't big enough to print that, you can sub a piece of 1/8" wood in it's place.

Expansion pieces
4-way and 3-way corners for making it deeper, wider, etc..
Sleeves for expanding the uprights - Just put sleeve into top of upright and slide next one onto it.

I have NOT load tested this yet.. If you want to load test this, please share your results and the method you used to test it.
Yes, the boxes in the picture are full boxes of PLA and Wood PLA. (Printed with Glow in dark PLA)

This did take a little while to draw, please feel free to tip if you like it.. :)

Update 1/21/18 - Oops, I forgot to include the top plate.. Added..

Update 1/22/18 - Added a leg spacer for the bottom of the legs. This should help stabilize the bottom of the legs if you put the shelf high.

Update 1/23/18 - Added assembly view showing one way to expand it - Also uploaded a couple pictures of the one I'm starting. I used the 4-way corners so I could expand.

Update 1/26/18 - I drew up a cross support. It hooks into the lower bar of the main truss and uses a small ring similar to how the corners work. I'm testing it now, and should have the STL files loaded tomorrow. Stay tuned. - These are optional, but should help make it even more solid so you don't need to glue it.

Update 1/27/18 - Optional pieces - Added the cross supports and an assembly view showing how they attach. These work by attaching a small ring to the lower area of the leg and hooking in a cross piece that attaches to the truss on the opposite side. Depending on if you glued your assembly together and how many shelves you put into it, you may or may not need these. But,, just in case you have a wobble, this is one solution to help stabilize it.

Update 2/11/18 - Added ability to wall mount. I have not tested this yet. The "WM" files are specifically for mounting to the wall. There is a truss and special corners to make this possible. This is 100% compatible with everything else here, so it can be used as an expansion. Also, the lower rear truss mount is to be GLUED to the leg. This should be fairly stable.
Yes, you can mount a section to the wall, and stack on top of that with the other pieces. I do recommend you use anchors and use the wall mount corners for extra vertical sections.
Also in this update was a half plate if you have a printer smaller than 200x200.
I have not test printed the wall mounting hardware yet, please let me know if somethings not right.

Resolution:

Tested on 0.3

Infill:

20% or better

Notes:

I set the walls to 1.2 with my 0.4mm nozzle and the cross trusses print quick with no infill needed.
If you are having adhesion issues, try printing with a brim.
Raft is not recommended.

  • Print the corners upside down so the locking hole comes out correct.
  • Print the uprights straight up and down as shown.
  • Print the trusses on their side as shown.
  • The assembly view is not meant to be printed, just shows how this assembles.
  • The crossing N-style trusses are meant to be tight, but if they are too tight, you can adjust your Z scale to 98-99% to make it a little thinner. Print one and test it before printing the whole batch.
  • Assembly tip on the locking rings for the corners - If they are sliding around too much when you go to put the corner on, use a small piece of tape to hold them in place.
  • Print the leg spacers diagonal on your printer if you have a 200mm bed like me.

Everything should fit nice and tight.
Since different filaments will shrink and expand differently, you may need to slightly sand the crossing truss connections. They should be snug. Glue the cross trusses if needed, but no glue needed anywhere else.

No glue needed for the uprights and the sleeves, the more weight on the corner piece, the tighter it grips.

If you have a wobble.... Many things can cause this, but a couple solutions for you.

  1. Glue the main trusses in place. (Do this after you get the spacing set with a leg spacer.)
  2. Anchor the top similar to how you would secure a book shelf.
  3. Install lower shelves.
  4. I'll be making some cross supports soon...

I had some wire racking in my garage, and I was thinking, it would be nice to have something expandable like that in my office on my desk.
I noticed there wasn't any design for this yet, so I took some time to draw it.
I made this expandable so it can be made to fit whatever space it's needed.

This could probably use a few tweaks. I think the ends of the key may need to be beveled just a little to aid in sliding in, and maybe a friction notch somewhere along the key length. description.text:

** Update 1/25/2018

** Update 2/10/2018
I have remove antibacklash holes.
There is no clearance for bolts with those.
Only use the Z stabiliers if your threaded rod is 100% true. if not it will bind up and break the inner brackets thin wall for the nut.

** Update 2/18/2018
-Created motor mounts. They allow you to move the motor to try and straighten the rod. These allow the rod to move Y and the bracket that holds the 2020 allows yout to move X.

** Update 3/4/2018
Use the motor mounts. The alignment if the z brackets is off if you don't. Do not use z rod stabilizers with this.

description.text: Cup for pen and pencil

// response to openscad screw threads with linear_extrude by speedymollusc
// For OpenScad coders.

// A slice through a bolt has the shape of a shallow heart.
// If we look at it radially from zero to 180 degrees,
// it increases linearly from the minor to the major radius.
// At zero degrees it will have the radius of the minor radius of the threads
// at 90 degrees it will be at the pitch radius
// then at 180 degrees it will be at the major radius.
// It's the same on the other side of the heart just mirrored across the X axis.

// This shape is made in module MaleThread using a polygon
// with a point on the X axis at radius [MinorTR+j/180*TH,0]]
// this simple equation just progresses from the minor radius
// to the major radius as j (the angle) goes from 0 to 180
// Then this polygon is rotated j degrees to the proper position on the heart.
// This is hulled and then mirrored to the create the other half of the heart.

// three examples are given a .5 inch NPT pipe thread , a .5 inch 13TPI bolt thread
// and an artistic thing so you can see the heart of it all

description.text:
Please read this for printing info!

Hey guys! To celebrate the launch of GRLC I made a Garlicoin you can print IRL. For more information on cryptocurrency, garlicoin etc please visit reddit.com/r/garlicoin . This model is my own creation and was not commissioned by the creators, just something I made for fun. There's two versions here, one with "In Garlic We Trust" printed on the side and one without. The writing will come across much clearer the higher your resolution and the less z wobble you have. I printed in .2 resolution so I could test and get this up and running for launch day. A resolution of .1 will make the text detail show up better, or you could scale this thing up, which you will need to do any way in Cura :) I'll probably mess with the "In Garlic We Trust" a little more to make it stand out better. For now, have fun!

description.text: This model is a replacement part for the plastic part that holds the pin to the jack stand so that it doesn't get lost.

  • 250/50 degree celsius
  • 5/5 speed
  • .2 layer
  • 2 shells
  • 25% infill
  • no support material is needed.

• After the part cools, the hole should slip tightly over the pin.

  • insert the end of the print, into the small hole in the print, to make a knot so the holder doesn't pull out.

description.text: Remember Mr. Six? You remember, the old dancing guy with the Six Flags bus. A while back I came across a rebirth commercial the chain had made back in the early 00's. Recently I watched it out of nostalgia and noticed this little button he pushed to start the iconic "We like to Party" theme song that is synonymous with the chain. So I decided to mocking it up on a whim. This is the definition of a quick and dirty model as there's no electronics and I kinda cheated by retrofitting the back of the button plate with a sleeve for an iPod, so the button is a glorified pause play button. author: Y123

description.text:
Winters are harsh on planet Pentatonia. On particularly cold days, the compounds of its toxic atomsphere deposit and crystalize. On their way down, the crystals collide and aggregate into larger and larger structures of alien shapes -pentatonian snowflakes.

The snowflakes snap together in various structures, the most spectacular of which is the spiky globe that consists of twelve snowflakes. With a pixel ring in the center it becomes an alien disco lamp. Beam me down, it's party time!

My little helper, Anna, assembles the disco lamp.

Size and amount of clearance between the parts are available as parameters (see BlocksCAD model). You can also choose to generate support. When printing in PLA I got the best result with support, but it printed fine in PETG without any support.

The construction of the snowflake is an exercise in classic geometry, It is based on the polyhedron known as the great stellated dodecahedron, which is what you get if you place pyramids on each of the twenty faces of an icosahedron. A group of five such pyramids/faces form the basis of the snowflake.

Three snowflakes meet at each face of the icosahedron, which means that each of the snowflakes's five "spikes" corresponds to one third of a "pyramid". The base of the pyramid is a regular triangle and the three snowflakes meet at its center. We call the shape of the spike's base a diamond.

A total of twelve snowflakes gives us 5 x 12 = 60 spikes, each of which is a "pyramid" cut in three. Let's see 60/3 = 20, yeah, that should match the number of pyramids on the stellated polyhedron and the number of faces the icosahedron, which we started from.

The base of the snowflake is flat and forms a pentagon. Two snowflakes meet at each edge of that pentagon. This is where we are going to attach the snowflakes to each other. The pentagons form the faces of the dodecahedron, which is inscribed in the stellated polyhedron. In particular, this means that the snowflakes meet at an angle that is about 116 degrees, the dihedral angle of a dodecahedron.

We started out from an icosahedron, which has twenty triangular faces and twelve corners; five faces meet at each corner. By interchanging the roles of the faces and the corners, we instead got the dual polyhedron, the dodecahedron with twelve faces that are pentagons and twenty corners, at each of which three faces meet.

To make the shape a little bit more complex and interesting two extra features were added: a smaller copy of the "spike" and a star-shaped "ring". Just for looks!

The triangular "wedges", however, play an important role; they form the hinges by which the whole structure snaps together. At each of the five sides of the base there is a "wedge" and a socket for the wedge of another snowflake.

Finally, a short description of the BlocksCAD project. As can be seen from the screen shot, there are three blocks of code that are larger than the others. They are placed to the left. From the top-down there are three modules called MakeSnowFlake, MakeBranchThatSnaps and MakeBranch.

MakeBranch creates the main spike, the smaller extra spike and one fifth of the ring. Two helper modules are used for this: MakeSpike and MakeRingSegment. MakeSpike works by doing a linear extrude of the 2D-shape that MakeDiamond creates.

MakeBranchThatSnaps adds the triangular wedge and the socket, which are used to attach the snowflakes to each other, It uses MakeTriangle to do just that.

MakeSnowFlake, finally, creates five copies of the-branch-that-snaps and (optionally) creates a staircase to support the overhang of the leaning spikes. A parameter determines whether to generate support or not. There are also parameters that control the size of the snowflake and the amount of clearance between snowflakes (there's gotta be a little tolerance or they won't fit).

In addition to the parameters, there are plenty of other things that could be tweaked quite easily. The length of the spikes, for instance, you could make them blunt and tubby or or longer and spikier. Why not make more of them? Download AlienDiscoLamp.xml from the ThingFiles and go to the BlocksCAD web page if you want to tweak the code yourself.

title: Anycubic i3 Mega Octopi holder for right z-axis
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I wanted to mount my Raspberry Pi-Zero on the Z-Axis, moving along the print. The right Z-Axis sheet metal chassis on my printer has a 10mm hole at the front which can be used to mount a clip.

This clip is then used to mount an adjustable arm to move the Raspiberry to safe distance from the X-Axis carriage.

Finally, a holder for the Raspberry chassis is screwed to the arm. I used Thing 2328261 as case for the Raspberry W Zero.

Beware

The things are a work in progress with much room for improvement.

I used very small m3 screws (4 - 5 mm) I just had lying around; you can't use longer screws since they will hit the frame.

The holder for the case is too weak yet; it must redesigned with a longer screw if one wants to avoid superglue or other "solutions".

Let me know what you think or remix the thing right away. Fusion360 design can be made avialable but it isn't pretty.

Update

  • Moved the arm 1 mm away from the chassis
  • Made the holder much more massive
  • Turned around screw and hex nut of holder (you'll need M3x30)
  • Tilted the holder 10 degrees for better view

small bowl with lid..

Customizable scanning electron microscopy pin mount rack

Make sure to customize the settings according to your needs. The STLs are designed so that the pin mounts slide in easily but do not squeeze in tightly to allow fast sorting and short transportations. For a tighter fit, reduce Inner Rad and increase Inner Height.

I'm happy for every make upload :-)

Enjoy scanning!

Settings

  • Number X: how many holder positions in x direction

  • Number Y: how many holder positions in y direction

  • Handle: 0 = no; 1 = yes (Number X must be even if Handle = 1)

  • Outer Rad: inner radius of outer cylinder

  • Outer Height: height of outer cylinder

  • Inner Rad: inner radius of inner cylinder

  • Inner Height: height of inner cylinder

  • Thickness: wall thickness of cylinders

  • Base Width: width and length of base plate for each cylinder
  • Base Height: height of the base plate

  • Base Width Handle: space for handle in base plate

  • Handle Rad Base: basal radius of handle
  • Handle Rad Top: top radius of handle

  • Handle Height: handle height

  • Fa: minimum angle for a fragment (smoothness setting)
  • Fs: minimum size of a fragment (smoothness setting)

title: Magnetic Blower Duct for Titan Aero

description.text:
This is a blower mount that magnetically attaches to the stepper motor on a titan aero setup.
You will need 6mm / 0.25 Inch magnets to shove into the holes on top. I used these:
https://www.amazon.ca/gp/product/B01NCKNB9M

Fan needed is a 50mmx50mmx15MM blower fan. I think a remix of this design for a 30x30x10mm would be a great idea since this fan seems overkill.

The nice thing about this is you can just grab the fan and stick it on your frame when printing ABS to save weight on the print head. Airflow is almost too good.. at 50% I can't maintain 260 degrees on my print head so for high temps maybe keep it to 25%.

Update: Installed an E3D silicone sock and now I can run 100% fan.. benchies are pretty much perfect at 100% compared to 50% so I think this might be the ideal setup.

I printed with flame retardant ABS since the duct is in such close proximity to the hot end.

FLSUN I3

40%

The second iteration of my Apple Pencil case! The original one can be found here.

This case is designed for use the iPad Pro with with a Smart Cover or Smart Keyboard. It houses the Pencil, the end cap, the charging adapter, four tips, and adheres magnetically to the keyboard. This case features a better-designed magnet installation method over the previous version, with screw cap holds and stronger magnets for a better hold on the smart cover or smart keyboard, softer corners, and a more refined design.

I recommend the lid with grips, and the screw caps with holds.

Assembly is very simple, just print off a base, one of the lid styles, and 8 of the screw caps to hold the magnets in place. Insert a magnet into each of the screw caps, and torque them into place using your fingers or needlenose pliers for grip.

This design requires 8 magnets, 4 for attaching the case to the iPad cover, and 4 to attach the lid. The magnets required for this are 12 x 3 mm disks, like these:
Amazon link 1, Amazon link 2, Amazon link 3, Apex Magnets, eBay.

Feel free to leave comments and suggestions! This piece came about because of people requesting edits, so please fell free to ask.

title: Joy Robot (Robô Da Alegria)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
First Prize in the Instructables Wheels Contest, Second Prize in the Instructables Arduino Contest, and Runner up in the Design for Kids Challenge. Thanks to everyone who voted on us!!!
http://www.instructables.com/id/Joy-Robot-Rob%C3%B4-Da-Alegria-Open-Source-3D-Printed-A/

Robots are getting everywhere. From industrial applications to underwater and space exploration. But my favorite ones are those used for fun and entertainement! In this project a DIY robot was designed to be used in children's hospitals, bringing some fun to the kids. The project is focused in sharing knowledge and promoting technological innovation to assist NGOs that carry out charitable work in children's hospitals.

I this project a remotely operated humanoid robot was designed, controlled over a Wi-Fi network, using an Arduino Uno connected to an ESP8266 Wi-Fi module. It uses some servomotors form head amd arms movements, some DC motors for moving small distances, and a face made of LED matrices. The robot can be controlled from an ordinary internet browser, using a HTML designed interface. An Android smartphone is used to broadcast video and audio from the robot to operator's control interface.

The whole structure of the robot was 3D printed, and it uses open hardware and open software at its core.

Full instructions at instructubles.com:
https://www.instructables.com/id/Joy-Robot-Rob%C3%B4-Da-Alegria-Open-Source-3D-Printed-A/

Special thanks to the other team members involved in the project:
-Thiago Farauche
-Diego Augustus
-Yhan Christian
-Helam Moreira
-Paulo de Azevedo Jr.
-Guilherme Pupo
-ASEBS

Find more about the project:
https://hackaday.io/project/12873-rob-da-alegria-joy-robot
https://www.hackster.io/igorF2/robo-da-alegria-joy-robot-85e178
https://www.facebook.com/robodaalegria/

How can you help?

This project is funded by team members and small donations from some enterprises. If you liked it, there are some ways you can help us:

  • Donation: you can send us tips if you want to support the construction of the robot and its future improvements. The tips will be used to buy supplies (electronics, 3d printing, filaments, etc.) and to help the promotion of our interventions in children's hospitals. Your name will de added to the credits of the project!
  • Like: Show us how much you appreciate our project. Give us a "like" on the platforms we document our project (Facebook, Hackster, Hackaday, Maker Share, Thingiverse...).
  • Share: Share the project on your favorite social media website, so that we can reach more people, and inspire more makers around the world.

Did you know you can buy the Anet A8 for only $145.99? Use the coupon code A8KIDA at Gearbest and get yours: http://bit.ly/2kqVOdO

https://www.instructables.com/id/Joy-Robot-Rob%C3%B4-Da-Alegria-Open-Source-3D-Printed-A/

The robot structure was entirely produced with 3D printing using Autodesk Fusion 360. In order to enable the production of robot replicas in makerspaces or fab labs, where the maximum time of use of the printers is crucial, the design of the robot was divided in pieces smaller than three hours of printing each. The set of parts is glued or bolted for body mounting.

The model is composed of 36 different parts. Most of them was printed without supports, with 10% infill.

remixed_from.author: punkkills
remixed_from.title: Micro 105 FPV Quadcopter - 8.5mm Motors, Micro Scisky

description.text:
This is a modified version of Punkkills' popular micro 105 FPV quadcopter frame. The original frame, while great, tended to break after fairly small crashes. After going through three frames, I decided to make some modifications to make the design more durable.

I smoothed corners to remove stress concentrations and braced the arms to improve rigidity. I have crashed this frame dozens of times and have only broken the arms in one spot which I simply glued back into place.

This is only the bottom frame. Print the top piece from Punkkills model.

Additionally here is a pro tip to avoid breaking your motors in a crash. Add a spacer between the prop and the motor housing. This prevents the shaft from being rammed into the bottom of the motor casing in a crash, which could result in breaking the bottom piece. Also add a good dab of hot glue under the motor where the motor sits in the frame. This will strengthen the bottom of the motor, hold the motor on the frame, and reduce strain on the motor leads .

I made these spacers for my CR-10S that clip on to the side rails at the rear and provide two functions.

First they keep the printer away from the wall so that if the clip's handles that hold the glass on to the table are extended rearward they do not hit the wall stopping the table causes belt or servo slippage.

Second, and the real reason I made them, is to guide the wires for the bed heater preventing them from dropping down below the rail when the table moves rearwards then snagging the cable on the corner of the rail when the table moves forward again. Saw that happen and realized that is not good...

The rear vertical end cap slides in to a slot in the spacer holding it in place. It is a tight fit so relieve any flashing that might be on any of the edges of both pieces. There is a provision for a M3 Flat Head screw to hold the two pieces together. The hole in the end cap is sized so that it can be tapped with a M3x0.5mm tap before assembly. Or once the pieces are assembled you can also use the screw itself to cut the threads in the end caps hole. That has been tried and found to work.

Careful installation onto the printers rails is necessary to prevent the clips from breaking off. Tilt the spacer to one side and get the two clips on the same side into the middle opening of the rail, i.e not all the way down/on. Then carefully push down the other side getting those remaining two clips into the middle opening of the rail on the other side.

Then line up the opening that fits over the rear cross rail and with one firm solid motion push the spacer down so the clips snap on engaging the bottom edge of the rail.

If a spacer needs to be removed it can be done but slowly and patiently is the key. First carefully pull on the inside two clips just enough to clear the rail and move them up to get them in the rail's middle opening. Then do the same with the outer two clips. Then again tilting the spacer pull the two clips on one side out, up, and over the top of the rail.

Created this item out of 20mm plate steel in order to be able to get the surface for my large delta printers (over 1.2 meters tall) to be level and not change over time (this will not flex of warp). In the past I have had them sitting on the concrete floor which was relatively level but a pain to work on. I have now moved the room they were in to one with carpet and wanted to put them up on a desk but this meant the desk was not level and I did not want to have to put shims in everywhere.

The plate has 5 x 10mm holes drilled and tapped (one on each corned and an extra one in the middle of one side). 2 bolts are on the corners of the front and one on the middle of the back edge are used to set the level (three legs is the only way to level something). There are then 2 additional legs on the comers on the back used to ensure it can't rock and are only lightly extended (I have cut slots in these so I can use a screwdriver from the top to wind them down till they touch the table top).

Metal Workshop Needed

I had these created at a metal fabricator as 20mm steel plate is not something most people can cut at home nor drill and tap for the 10mm bolts. The item ways about 30kg so adds additional stability to the printer which is also tied to the plate preventing any swaying due to the mass at the top of the Tevo LM.

title: GameClip for encased Samsung Galaxy S6

description.text:
This is a model based on bernabap's GameClip. It holds a Samsung Galaxy S6 with a thin TPU-case (72mm wide, 8mm thick) to the PS3 controller (Dualshock 3). I placed the phone over the controller for a better center of gravity so it takes less effort to hold.

Expert Cura users only: I also included two volumes for more detailed infill and excluding support. For this you need the per-model-settings and mesh features in Cura v3.1.0+. You can use them to remove all supports where you most certainly don't need them (anti overhang mesh) and increase the infill at the weak spot around the Home Button (infill mesh; I recommend overall infill of ~25% with 2 walls and 90% infill for the infill mesh). Just merge the objects when you applied all settings.
