remixed_from.author: thing6he
remixed_from.title: Ergonomic handgripp for Asus Xtion Pro Live

title: A4K2: Stereo Capture rig for Canon A4000

description.text:
This is a simple hand-held mount that we designed in 2014 for a pair of Canon PowerShot A4000 cameras to capture synchronized stereo images or video.

The camera mount is our own design, holding a pair of A4000 so that the stereo baseline approximates that of human vision. The cameras can be screwed-in via their tripod sockets, or can be secured using tie straps, but they actually clip in well enough for normal use. The grip (which was derived from Thing 62606) is hollowed to accept a standard 9V battery, momentary switch, and dual-port USB connector (to which we wired a 7805 voltage regulator). Thus, the wiring in the grip allows for a regulated 5V to be supplied to both USB port connectors when the button is pressed, and CHDK allows the cameras to be triggered at precisely the same time by detecting that 5V signal on the camera USB ports.

The reason we didn't post this design earlier was the awkwardness of using the 9V battery and regulator as the 5V source -- a rechargeable USB battery would be the correct answer now. However, this design is discussed in Lessons from design, construction, and use of various multicameras at Electronic Imaging 2018, so, here it is....

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

MakerGear M2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.25mm or finer

Infill:

about 25%

Notes:

PLA works fine. The two pieces print separately and slide together after the battery and wiring have been installed in the handle. It's an easy print except for the span over where the dual USB socket goes -- you might want some support for that, although some sag really just helps the USB socket fit more firmly.

Installing the 9V battery is easy, but fitting the switch, 7805 regulator, and dual USB socket into their places isn't as easy. In any case, you'll need to wire them together before putting them in. A little hot glue, or shaping of the PLA using a soldering iron on the inside, can be used to firmly set the switch and connector in place.

author: emre1393

description.text:
These are the bearings I use for the upper mounts. They are F608zz. The 688s in the stock mounts get used in the lower section.

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01DWVIBJU

Printing instructions:

Minimum 4 outer walls, 6 top walls/bottom solid layers, 50% infill.

If you're not printing perfectly accurate, scale down the insert slightly.

Installation:

install f688z and top plug into mount, do not install bottom plug yet.

move the x gantry up as high as you can

remove motor and motor mount, loosen or disconnect the coupler

unmount the ball screw bearing

Install the upper mount. Ensure it is pushed all the way up against the vertical frame.

slide the motor mount into position, it will be tight, but you should be able to get the ball screw into the f688z bearing. You'll need to drop the lower tnut into the channel and get it aligned. The top can stay attached to the bolt.

ensure the t-nuts are seated properly.

tighten down the T nuts, but leave loose. They need to be horizontal otherwise there will not be enough room

push up on the motor mount so that there is no play in the ball screw in the bearings then tighten the bottom t-nut.

ensure the ball screw moves freely. If it does, install the other insert and tighten the top t-nut.

install motor and coupling. Push coupling up as high as you can without touching the mount.

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

minimum 50%

remixed_from.title: Anet A8 Prusa i3 bed leveling knob

title: Helical Gear Bed Level Knob with Captive Nut

description.text:
I really like the "Captive Nut" idea, and I make a lot of gears, so I thought I would combine them in this print.
I didn't use the Cura plugin to pause the print. Instead I monitored the percent status on the Anet display, and paused at 65% to insert the M3 nuts. I had calculated the layers in Cura (I think it was layer 46 (of 69 total) just before it would start to close the hex pocket). Worked great.
I modeled this in Fusion 360 with the Helical Gear generator, then modified it with the hex pocket and thru hole. The pocket is 0.1" deep (2.54mm) and the M3 nuts I used are .093" (2.37mm). This is to make sure you can insert the nuts fully and be below the print layer that will cover it. Make sure the nuts are pushed in as far as they can go before resuming the print, otherwise you risk running over the steel nut and damaging the print nozzle! (I learned this the hard way).

Thanks to Ratm3at for the inspiration to try this!
Goes great with the Spring Bushing by Puddlefist!

I really like the Jeep Yeti Handle by rrichey so I printed it for my wife in her favorite color Pink. Well the original is designed for a 30oz Yeti mug so I had to scale it down to 87% to get it to fit my wife's 20oz Yeti mug. This made the handle a little too close for my wife to comfortably hold onto the handle even with her small hands. So I began the process of translating the provided STL file from rrichey's post into an editable CAD file which makes the files much larger. This was my first attemp at this and it took awhile but my wife in the end was happy with the newly designed handle that sits further away from the mug and is a bit larger for a better hold. I also removed the notch gap between the handle and the mug ring, which my wife said made it easy for her to get a finger caught in a little bit. The newly designed handle also prints better as it has steeper overhangs.

As always, I have also posted my source file as a STEP (.stp) file so others can easily customize the design. STEP files can be opened in a variety of CAD packages, such as AutoDesk's FREE to use Fusion 360.

There is also a 30oz version of this handle, but I have not printed it as we don't have 30oz Yeti mugs. It is a scaled version, 115%, of my V2 20oz design so everything including the handle will be larger. Or you can always use rrichey's original design which is for a 30oz mug.

Enjoy!

I just don't get why 3D printer designers provide terrible Z axis adjustment. I guess it is so people like me have a mission.

I like the Tronxy X3S pre-built printer except for the lousy Z axis adjustment (also the print bed isn't all that great). I added the MatterHackers magnetic build plate to fix the print bed issue.

Here is my fix for the Z axis adjustment. Use a 5mm x 70mm screw, standard nut and nylock nut. The nylock inserts in the lower bracket and keeps the adjustment locked in. The standard nut is inserted in the adjusting nut which is 12mm and can be turned with a wrench or hex driver.

Not perfect, but far better than stock.

Enjoy!

remixed_from.author: FDM_Guru
remixed_from.title: MP Select Mini Side Cooling Panel Mod

title: MPSM cable chain, side mount, no drilling bed re-wiring

description.text:
I found a few bed re-wiring projects for the select mini, but didn't want to drill holes in the original parts in case I wanted to have the original look back and I didn't want the footprint to be affected too much on the back of the machine since my bench is quite narrow.

So I combined the cable chain from ModelStation and the passive side cooling vent from FDM_Guru. I modified the chain ends to make them attach to the bed carriage and to the side panel.

The cables I used are way overkill, but that's what I had on hand. It barely fitted through de chain. Also, the hole on the side panel is a very tight fit for the connector to the PCB, so I recommend feeding the wires first or filing it open a tiny little bit.

I used 16 links of chain, but I think I should have added 2 or 3 more, as the chain doesn't fold as flat as I would like.

But hey, it's my first lengthy mod on this printer. I'm happy with the way it turned out !

View it in action :

https://youtu.be/qAW3rzQ0HX8

Huge thanks to original model makers !

comments.text: Well done! The only edit I would suggest is that the dimensions from the ported side panel that actually mounts to the cable chain are off by a factor of 10 i.e. it's 10 times bigger than it should be. It's not a huge deal, just a matter of convenience for people who want to order them printed.

Looking for a better tool for removing prints from the 3D printer, I thought a medium sized flexible putty knife that was sharpened might be good if used bevel-down. I purchased a 1 1/4" Warner putty knife and ground a bevel on one side. It works great on non-tape surfaces, but it's crazy sharp and I'm nervous transporting it. So I thought I'd print a cover for it.

This was designed in Onshape. You can copy and modify it here: https://cad.onshape.com/documents/7b21ad6d859d2b624ab5fa53/w/863b1850d8ae58bb6da0c443/e/e4779f5be0a5e9d26795164a

My Monoprice Mini Delta printer tends to print undersized (I'm thinking it doesn't take PLA shrinkage into account in the firmware) so I adjusted in the design. So you may need to increase the size by 2-3%.

This friction fits onto the tip of the knife just fine. The print in the pictures is a bit ugly but this was a test print and it's functional.

title: Optical drive bay to hard drive bay sled or rails

description.text:
Use this to fit a 3.5" hard drive into a half-height (5.25" optical drive) bay. I used dimensions from the following two standards: 3.5" disk drive:
SFF-8301: ftp://ftp.seagate.com/pub/sff/SFF-8301.PDF
5.25" optical drive
SFF-8851: ftp://ftp.seagate.com/sff/SFF-8551.PDF You can print either a full sled with a base plate, or just rails for the sides. If you use this, please feedback. Sorry about the messy code.

Print out. Place 3.5" hard drive. Use 3.5 mm or #6 hard drive screws to affix to sled. The file is heavily commented, and comments like //A1 and //A14 refer to the dimensions given by the SFF-8301 and SFF-8851 standards mentioned in the top comment. Some variables of note include:
$manifoldOverlap
$screwRad
$minWallThickness;
$minScrewAllowance

comments.text: They are the right size but word of warning, the back holes are not accessible I had to drill another hole through the side for the screwdriver.

title: QYo - Spec C / Half C Ball Bearing Yoyo

description.text:
This is a good beginner Yoyo! Great to give to someone who may not be into yoyo but may be curious. It even plays well with no bearing at all!

Designed for Spec C yoyo bearing but of course will fit the Half Spec C as well. Threaded for 12mm M4x.07 grub screw, but with depth to accommodate the thinner bearing with the same axle. Response pad version fits standard 19mm od / 14.5mm id response pads.

Please let me know if you have any requests!

Version 2 adds a cup to the outside in an attempt to shift weight to the rim.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200nm

Infill:

15% - 100% See Below

Notes:

Please rotate the STL until the outside of the yoyo is flat on your build plate (rotate about the Y axis 90 degrees). No supports needed for PLA.

For Original (flat sided): 7-10 perimeters, 5 bottom layers (unless you want the infill to be a feature, set this to 0), 5 top layers, 15% infill and 'fill gaps' turned on.

For V2 (cups on the side): 5 perimeters and 0.2mm slice height. Trust me, use 5 perimeters. 100% infill unless your printer will pile up, if it is struggling drop it to 90%.

You want it to weigh just over 20 grams per half. Getting it heavy enough is a challenge. Careful of the thin wall on the ones with the response pad groove.

This is my first "Hello World" design created with BlocksCAD, aka "Hello Snowflake".

BlocksCAD is a 3D design tool with a blocks-based programming interface, which is quite easy to use - you can create shapes, move and rotate them in the three-dimensional coordinate system, or recursively perform an action by using loops.
It'd be a wonderful 3D design tool for STEM students to have fun with 3D design and learn visual programming concepts, or for anyone who would like to get up and running with 3D design without having the learn the intricates of 3D design tools.

This Thing contains the main Fusion 360 project file (Corner table.f3d) that I used to create a flat-pack corner table for my apartment.

The design has some parametric functionality that you can play with in Fusion 360 under Modify > Change Parameters. Most important of which is the Thickness_Global parameter that should be set to the real measured thickness of the stock you use.

All parts were routed out of 3/4" birch plywood using a low-end 4x4' CNC router at my local makerspace.

All CAM (toolpath) profiles are included in the project file and are optimized for my particular CNC machine. At a minimum you should verify or adjust the feeds, speeds, tool parameters, and stepdown to match the requirements of your machine.

author: glsalazar

print_settings.Notes:: My only suggestion is to use white or other bright filament.  The problem with a black trap is that if you put it in a dark space like your crawlspace, it's hard to see - and that goes double for the bait holder.  This trap should be bright white so you can find it.  I doubt the rats care, as all they care about is peanut butter and pooping.

description.text:
Do you have rats? Do you have the Tomcat brand "Rat Snap Trap" traps and keep losing the bait holders in your crawlspace entrance when the trap goes off and the holder goes flying and it's black plastic in a dark space with black plastic on the ground? Do you have a 3D printer? Well stop right now, and print this replacement!

I've done a few tweaks like adding some little bumps to help the holder stay in place, and I have two versions with different bump heights. You may find one of them is a better fit.

Probably the main thing to watch out for is if your layers aren't adhered well, you may have it split apart when you turn the bait holder to tighten it in.

Notes:

My only suggestion is to use white or other bright filament. The problem with a black trap is that if you put it in a dark space like your crawlspace, it's hard to see - and that goes double for the bait holder. This trap should be bright white so you can find it. I doubt the rats care, as all they care about is peanut butter and pooping.

I started with a new trap and the bait holder. I did some basic measurements of it with a cheapo (but wonderfully useful) digital micrometer. And of course at some point, I dropped the original on the floor in my .... er... creative workspace, and lost it. So I had to kind of wing it from there.

Actual modelling was done with Tinkercad. You can grab and modify the original at https://www.tinkercad.com/things/6IqJ7uWYmRV-rat-trap-bait-holder
Enjoy!

My wife and I escaped the cold Nebraska winter for a short time between Jan. 13 - 20, 2018, and enjoyed the Eastern Caribbean on a Disney Cruise! One of the coolest parts of the going on a Disney Cruise is decorating your stateroom door with magnets. It's a fun way to add a personal touch and easily identify your room.

title: Sony RX100 shutter release & centering ring

description.text:
A friend of mine wanted to use the BULB mode to shoot night scenes on his RX100M1. It doesn't accept any electric shutter release, and so this is what I came up with. It allows him to lock the shutter down for as long as he wants. With a less sturdy tripod it might still be necessary to cover the lens before and after, incase of movement.

Shout out to Motorpixiegimbals for the centering ring adapter, saved me lots of time.

There is a through-hole on the bolt so that it might work with a mechanical shutter release trigger. If somebody has one and can spec the threads, I'd love to integrate that compatibility.

It uses a small taper head M3 bolt & heat set insert for the knob, but it functions without. (McMaster Carr 94180A331, 92125A128)

I've also included a plastic tripod bolt and nut.

Printer:

TEVO Tarantula

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

40

Notes:

Wanted it to be extra tough, so I made it 3 wall 40 infill. Some droop on the bridging but it works just fine.

For a loose fit, I scaled down the screw portion at 99%, but a dialed printer should work too.
Heat set an insert into the knob, use a screw to secure it in place. I put some loctite on there so that the knob and screw spin freely.

title: The Edelweiss
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hey guys it’s your boy タイガーエース1945 here to announce that from now on this page will be 100% anime 100% of the time! Please head on over to the world at war group to vote on your favorite tank-waifu to be ma………………………………..but seriously though, I had Valkyria Chronicles in my steam library for about 2 years now and I finally found the time to beat it. If you guys haven’t played it’s a Japanese game set in an alternate earth WW2 where you play as a militia group defending their home country Gallia (Poland/Belgium) against a military invasion from The Empire (Germany) on one side and espionage/political takeover by The Federation (Russia/Allies) on the other. Aside from the Anime components of the story (Honestly the most boring parts) the game not only focuses on but handles quite well some of the more touchy subjects of the war that are commonly ignored by most games. The game-play is a combination of turn based, first person shooter, and Real time strategy. I honestly don’t know how to explain it better but it’s a whole bunch of fun...... no I'm not being paid to say this, I actually liked the game.....

I probably won’t be doing much of these fantasy tanks in the future, but this one was allot of fun to make and allowed me to practice modeling techniques that aren’t usually used. Probably won’t be doing any more stuff from the game either…….but if for some crazy reason one of you motivated individuals would like to I don’t know write some board game rules or something shoot me a PM, I would love to help ………

Currently contains all Upgrades to the Edelweiss that change the in-game model

Standard Barrel (Gun-1)
Barrel Protector (Gun-2)
Reinforced Barrel (Gun-3)
Extended Barrel (Gun-4)
Standard Hull (Hull-1)
Additional Armor (Hull-2)

Reinforced Armor (Hull-4)
Standard Armor (Armor-1)
Frontal Armor (Armor-2)
Turret Armor (Armor-3)
Gun Barrel Armor (Armor-4)

All vehicles made from scratch

Please join my group http://www.thingiverse.com/groups/the-world-at-war/topics

Please view my other packs https://www.thingiverse.com/TigerAce1945/designs

title: Fossil Q Watch Stand - Removable Back

description.text:
This remix is based on Holodrio's Fossil Q Watch Stand. The original design required you to depend on extruded plastic as the screw mounts when attaching the back to the base, which I always find can't be used more than once before breaking. Since I didn't want the charger to be stuck in the base forever (or print a new stand every time I removed the charger), I've updated it to no longer depend on the plastic when screwing together.

The stand has been updated to have holes all the way through to hold 2 6-32 X 1 hex screws (see photo above) and are fastened in the back with two 6-32 knurled nuts (see photo above). Both of these can be found in just about any hardware store for very cheap.

The main benefit of adding these screws is it allows you to remove the charging pad for your watch in case you need to bring it with you.

No special printing needed. The top part of the stand is still the same as in Holodrio's design.

title: Wooden Knot Cross Puzzle, OCC, Three Pieces, Kong Ming Lock

description.text:
Wooden Knot Cross Puzzle, OCC, Three Pieces, Kong Ming Lock

This is a simple yet fascinating cross knot puzzle of three interlocking pieces. It may have a Chinese origin, dating back to the days of Zhuge Liang (aka. Kongming, AD 181-234). Easy as it looks, it takes a bit of planning in 3D design. One has to make sense of the physical constraints. While the length of each piece is largely arbitrary; its width has to be three times as much as its thickness. Further, one has to consider the tolerance. This makes a great entry-point 3D design project for STEM teachers and their students. Yes, a bit of struggle is healthy!

In the current design, I have added a 0.5mm tolerance to the OCC slots and a 0.25mm tolerance to the opening so that children can slide them back and forth smoothly. There are two styles with various widths and lengths. Have fun!

One way to adjust the tightness is playing with the resolution -- starting with say, 0.18mm. If it is too loose, go to 0.2mm. If it is too tight, go down to 0.12mm, etc. It depends on the printer.

References:

  1. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Burr_puzzle
  2. http://chinesepuzzles.org/interlocking-burr-puzzles/
  3. http://www.mathematische-basteleien.de/devilsknot.htm

title: Xiaomi Body detector (Motion detector) ceiling or wall mount

description.text:
This is a wall or ceiling mount bracket for the Xiaomi Human body sensor. (It's marketed as a human body sensor - it's essentially a motion detector). The sensors are super cheap, (Around $10USD) and they use the Zigbee protocol, so you can connect them to your Smarrthings hub. A4refill pad wrote a killer custom device type for it.
This bracket is designed to attach your sensor to the wall or ceiling using US common gold screws, drywall screws, or wood screws.
There's two versions, a simple one with the bottom screw mount only, and a more complex one with screw holes for mounting horizontally as well. For my printer, it took 22 minutes and about 1.64 meters of filament for the complex version. I went fast and light, because nobody should be seeing these. (5% infill, and 100mm/s) I used it to mount the xiaomi motion detector in a laundry room closet.
I've included the .f3d (fusion 360) files if you'd like to take a stab at remixing.

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
Since snowflakes are often seen as a pictograph for temperature so too is this one! Full R->G->B sweep from 15C-35C (60F-95F) and haptic mode control.

While its rotation and loop based rendering are certainly a standout feature I also I wanted to see how BlocksCAD went at building something functional that also included non-symmetric components. Was impressed with its ease of use and understanding.

Everything friction fits together. The board should snap onto the mounting lugs and the diffuser requires a little pressure to seat it into the base. For the diffuser white PLA works great, smoothing the LED light. The diffuser is very thin in parts (3 layers @ 0.2mm) to allow more passage of light in the snowflake pattern. Excuse the under extrusion on my diffuser ;) Support is only required for the internal battery compartment, easy to remove.

Inside is a battery or USB powered Adafruit Circuit Playground (code enclosed). There are many styles and sizes of lithium ion battery that can be used but the BlockCAD file has parameters for altering the battery size – another powerful feature. So long as the battery fits in the footprint of the overall design, which can also be set with parameters should you wish to enlarge the light projection area.

The default code has a few modes, starting with aforementioned temperature mode. Tapping the snowflake will take you through a few other pretty modes (see https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Be5zCj8a_cM ) and finally to OFF. But all this is easily editable in the code, including the temperature range. Likewise, you could edit the diffuser pattern to be anything!

print_settings.Notes:: Test fit pieces before putting game components into the boxes.

description.text:
Containers for Twilight Imperium 4th Edition.

While 4th Edition provides a nice, full box insert for the game, the insert is not well designed to handle cards with sleeves, nor does it make it easy to get at the players pieces.

So, 3D Printing to the rescue.

All containers have been designed with a .25mm gap around the lid. It's tight, but it's what worked to get a snug, but not permanent fit on my printer. You may need to scale up the lid slightly depending on your settings. (I printed at 0.2mm)

Test the fit before you put pieces in! I got carried away and fully closed a box that was full. had to destroy the box to get the pieces out again. If it's too tight, look for areas that might be sticking out (On the race boxes specifically, I always had one corner on the tray that had a slight bulge that I could trim with a knife)

Ship Boxes:
While I originally tried to make them fit within the confines of the insert, it just wasn't possible to fit all of the pieces and the cards as I wanted to do it. So I ended up with a slightly larger box, but still sized such that 3 of them sit along the short edge of the box.

The card section in the ship box holds all coloured technology cards, ship upgrades and the 4 common promissory notes for that colour. It's a tight fit with sleeves, but perfectly doable. There is a notch on the bottom of the tray so that the cards can slide out with ease in a pack.

Ship Bottoms took 10.5 hours to print at 60 mm/s. The lids took about 3.5 hours.

Race Boxes

While the design for 3rd edition was nice and had the command counters in a dedicated section, I decided to forego that design in favour of something more compact. Holds all tokens (including race specific tokens!) and all race-specific cards (Technologies, Home Planets, Race-specific promissory note)

As mentioned above, check the fit on this one before committing your pieces to the box! I had a slightly tighter fit on this one than expected that was caused by a small printing artifact (same start point on each layer caused a very slight bulge on one corner that was easily trimmed using a knife)

Lid and base printed at the same time took 3.5 hours to print one set at 60mm/s, 0.2mm layer height.

Card Tray
Holds all other sleeved cards for the game. Sections for Stage 1 Objectives, Stage 2 Objectives, Secret Objectives, Planets, Action Cards, Politics cards.

The model as provided does not have the symbols. I found they didn't print well, so opted to remove them.

Space Tiles
I've posted two versions of a hex holder for the space tiles. It's probably unnecessary to have the extra side along the top, but I thought it looked neat. Still, I provided both versions so you can choose which one you want to use.

Anything Else?
I've opted to use small containers for the dice, ground force / fighter / trade good tokens rather than design a specific box for them.

After I uploaded a 608 and 625 bearing designs, someone asked for a 688 bearing. I didn't really need one, but it doesn't take long to build, so I uploaded the design and included the fusion 360 example file.

Notes:

Note that you may need to force the inner ring a bit to make it move.

As with all small moving parts, the dimensional accurace and tolerance of your prints are important to get a working part. This means your printer should be reasonably well maintained to print accurately enough. There are various tolerance tests. If you can pass with 0.2mm tolerance, you should be able to make this work. Even if your printer can't get that level of accuracy, small adhesion with the ball can still be cleared by applying some force on the inner ring.

Choice of filament material can also make a difference. I noticed moving parts don't behave well in PLA, and can easily break. I use eSun PLA+ which seems to be a little more flexible. Use a filament that you had good results with.

Using Fusion 360 to draw bearings quickly

Once you have the dimensions of a bearing you need, draw a few concentric circles aroung the origin.

How to build bearings with dimensions (OD, ID, W) in fusion360.

T1. Draw center circle (C) Inner Diameter in mm (ID) - add 0.1mm to inner diameter if you want a loose fit that makes it easier to insert the bearing.
T2. Draw center circle (C) Outer Diameter in mm. (OD)
T3. Take E = OD-ID-1mm. Draw at ID+(E/2) (Use 1-2mm instead of 1mm if you like).
T4. Draw at OD-(E/2)
T5. Draw at TD = ID+(E/2) - this will be the extent of the Torus you need to draw.
T6. Using symmetric (and check the selection to the total, not just one side) Extrude (E) the inner ring and the outer ring to the width (W) you need for the bearing. There should be a 1mm (or bigger) gap in between.

T6. Create a Torus from center to the TD diameter. Make the width of the torus path cut the inner and outer rings as much as you like while still leaving enough material in the inner and outer rings. Remember this value.

T7, At a point on the perimeter at TD away from center, draw a sphere, make the diameter 0.4mm smaller than the value of the torus width. This gives a 0.2mm clearance each way.

T8. Create a circular pattern. Select Object and select the sphere. Create as many as will fit in the path cut by the torus while still leaving enough space in between the spheres.

I usually smooth out the sharp edges with a fillet. This is optional, but it is useful as the sharp edges can cut.

I have a small rechargeable cylindrical battery pack, and keep in plugged into my car to keep it charged. Being round, it has a tendency to want to roll around, so I decided to make a simple holder that could attach easily to the interior of my car and keep the battery pack handy.

Note that if you life in an area where the interior of you car gets above 50-60 degrees C (122-140 degrees F, which isn't really all that hot), standard PLA will start to deform, so you'll want to use high-temp PLA, ABS, PETG, Nylon, or other materials that can take the heat (my old Nove got up to 185 degrees F in the Dallas summer sun!).

This model is easy enough to modify for different size batteries, so if it doesn't fit your battery (or if you don't want your battery peeking over the top of the holder), then feel free to modify this or create your own battery holder.

title: Rear Arm Repair Brace - DJI Mavic Drone

description.text:
When the rear arms on the DJI Mavic break, its usually at the skinny section next to the motor. Simply gluing it does not provide enough strength because of the small cross section area. This brace bridges the broken pieces and also provides enough surface area for the epoxy.

Designed to print with a .4mm nozzle.

1) Print Solid ABS
2) clean drone arm with rubbing alcohol to remove any dirt & oils
3) carefully glue with 2 part epoxy, making sure to keep all glue away from the motor.
4) Clamp using a 5/8 thick Paper Binder Clip (walmart/Target/staples/OfficeMax)
5) Trim excess glue after epoxy starts to setup.

title: Stand, Clamps and Equipment Kit
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Stand, Clamps and Equipment Kit

This has so many different uses not only in chemistry. This kit can be used in engineering, Stop motion, biology, manufacturing and many more. This system made to be easy, quick and flexible for any application.

Why

For a project, I need to mount a microscope camera over a PCB and did not want to make a one-off mount. I thought about other ways of making it then thought how chemistry uses a system with rods to mount to. Looking at chemistry kits, there were parts that were not there but would be useful. It was decided that I would construct my own system based on the chemistry kits system.

Keep up to date

New Parts will be added, Keep up to date by following:
This Thing -> https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2765367
and my Profile -> https://www.thingiverse.com/haybailes/about

See Other Projects

Have a look at this and other projects that I have done: http://tinkersprojects.com/project/stand-clamps-and-equipment/

Equipment Components

Stands

There are 2 different types of stands, the first is made to be bolted to a plate of steel, acrylic or other base material. The second is a flexible stand where the legs can fold in/out to provide more room or avoid objects. Both stands use 10mm rods with M3 screws to hold them in place.

Bosshead

This attaches one rod to another rod at 90 degrees from each other. A 15mm x M3 screw with a nut holds the rods in place.

Clamp

This is to hold anything from a test tube and thermometer to cameras and probes. A screw will tighten the clamp around the object. A 10mm rod is inserted into the hole with some glue to hold it in place.

Ring Stand

Ring stands are used to hold a funnel but can also be used as a platform. The ring stand is made in 3 sizes; 50mm, 75mm, and 100mm. A 10mm rod is inserted into the hole with some glue to hold it in place.

Hook

This is used to hold something up, it could be cable, hose or something with a handle. A 10mm rod is inserted into the hole with some glue to hold it in place.

Angled Rods

Sometime the Rods would be better if they could bend to get a better angle or go around other objects without using more rods and bossheads. This can be done by using 2 rods attached together with a hinge to create a bendable rod. Half a bosshead and hinge can be used to anywhere on a rod. A 10mm rod is inserted into the hole with some glue to hold it in place.

PCB Holder

2 of these pars and be used to hold a printed circuit board (PCB) to the system for a time, displaying or as a soldering station. It clamps onto a 10mm rod and held in place with a 15mm x M3 screw.

Crocodile Clips Holder

This is to hold the wire, cables and other objects in place. This could be used as a soldering station for holding components. It clamps onto a 10mm rod and held in place with a 15mm x M3 screw.

Light Fitting

This is a light attachment when more light is needed. It uses a downlight screw connector to attach the light. The light which attaches to one-half of the angled rods and can be angled before tightening.

Wing Nut

This makes the system easy to use without the use of any screwdrivers and other tools. An extra 10mm is needed on the screws to uses this to on any part. (bosshead would require 25mm, not 15mm). A nut is inserted into the hole and the screw gets tightened through the part. Some glue would help to ensure the screw does not loosen.

And more to come

There will be many more parts to come. Keep an eye on this part to not miss them.

Note

  • Use a 10mm drill to drill out the holes for a better fit before inserting the rods.
  • The parts are 3d printed and a bunsen burner will melt the parts.

title: Wanhao/Monoprice laser mounting bracket
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Yet another laser mount for the Wanhao/Monoprice V2.1 printers. While I like the idea of using magnets to secure the laser to the printer for convenient installation/removal, it just doesn't feel like a safe thing to do. This bracket uses the location of the original hot-end cooling fan. Also this bracket has a place to install a SPDT switch for added laser safety during startup.

Use this part at your own risk!

I am not responsible for damage that you may incur to yourself, your property, or others. Class IV lasers are not toys and should be handled with extreme care. Wear appropriate eye protection at all times.

Have fun, but be careful.

Please let me know if you made one and/or if you like it. Feedback welcome!

1/23/18: First test burn on 1/4" plywood (Overwatch symbol). This was made by importing an image to FreeCAD, tracing (no pun intended), and padding to 0.25mm. Cura took care of the rest.
I just barely got the "Inkscape method" working this morning, so I will test that out this evening and post results. So far though, the bracket has been quite sturdy even at higher speeds.

Shelf

Display

  1. Press MKS TFT32 into TFT Face
  2. Secure with screws and nuts

Power Supply

  1. Slide in 12v power sully and make connections to power switch and MKS v1.4 board.
  2. Press fit power connector into back panel

Fans

  1. Mount three fans inside of front fan duct (pushing air in)
  2. Mount two fans on outside of fan,vent, power - back panel (pushing air in)

Cables

  1. Standard PC power cable connects to back panel
  2. Route all cables to printer through top port using cable management

title: Kodama: An array of three Insta360 Air cameras

description.text:
Kodama, which is named after the tree spirits it so closely resembles, is an array incorporating three Insta360 Air cameras in a very small mount that minimizes parallax and ensures all areas in the 360-degree view are seen by at least two of the component cameras.

Simultaneous capture of three 3008x1504 video streams over USB is a bit challenging for most laptops and even desktop computers. However, the resulting image data allows computing enhanced resolution, high dynamic range (HDR), image data with much finer temporal resolution supporting TDCI (Time Domain Continuous Imaging).

This design is discussed in Lessons from design, construction, and use of various multicameras at Electronic Imaging 2018.

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

MakerGear M2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25mm or finer

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Print in PLA. We used natural PLA to enhance the spirit-like appearance.

Although there are minor spans, any sagging will only act as a spring when the two halves are assembled, thus helping to secure the USB cables in place.

The two halves are held together using two 1/4-20 screws and nuts. The 3D-printed structure encloses and clamps into place the three Insta360 Air cameras and their USB cables.

The base of Kodama is designed to be directly compatible with the rapid-release clamp of the Sunpak 5400DLX tripod (which costs about $15). Alternatively, Kodam can sit on any flat surface.

Be careful when carrying Kodama: all six lenses are vulnerable. We recommend placing Kodama in a soft-lined pouch for transport.
This work was supported in part under NSF Award #1422811, CSR: Small: Computational Support for Time Domain Continuous Imaging.

title: Prusa i3 MK3 Feet Smart Lock

description.text:
Got your MK3, but tiered of the rubber feet falls off every time you move it!

No more! Just lock your rubber feet in place with this easy Smart Lock.

Installing:

  • No tools required!
  • Print four pairs of locks in your favorite filament.
  • No post print required, locks are ready to use.
  • Mount all rubber feet into extrusion as per MK3 instruction.
  • Follow instructions on photos to get the locks into place.

Your feet is now secured.

Uninstalling is easy too - Using the small slots in each lock part, pull the lock apart. You can use the Prusa plier with the tips in each slot and opening the plier to unlock.

Don't forget to like it, if you like it...

Alternative: Print new feet in TPU or Flex, with this design

title: Eric's Wade's Collaborative Dual Feed Extruder

description.text:
This is a new Extruder with TWO hobbed bolts for extrusion.  Two bolts means this is almost unstrippable. You should get fewer Jams and allow more pressure for smaller printheads.
I'm calling this Wades Collaborative Extruder because so many people have added so many great things to the Wades, Without all of you this would not be possible.

I've included my CREO PK2 file for your editing fun. Sorry it's got everything in it so it's a bit messy. I'll clean it up later. Also are the .STL's for what it is right now. Build like other "Wades" variant extruders, but with Dual Hobbed bolts.
There's quite a bit that still needs work. The new Latch for the top needs a good strong spring in the middle. The Drive gears need to be matched to the motor gear. I just need to add the STL's and do a little Mods to make the little gear taller. but right now it's setup with an extra nut on the threads to hold the little gear to the herringbone gears. (I didn't make the Herringbone, those were designed by others so I've left that out.) I need to Mod it for the Makerbot Groovmount. (5mm disc insert)Is Jhead right now. I need to buy more skate bearings to complete mine for testing. Concievably this could work for faster printing once it's refined. If you need any changes or exports please ask, I'm up for anything you want to help with or that you have better ideas for.

comments.text: Hi Curious_pl, We could use belt, but we would have to print the belt as well since finding a belt small enough would be difficult. Gears was much easier. Besides with a belt, the bolts would turn the same direction, with gears they turn opposite, which means they can turn on opposing sides of the filament. That makes it harder to strip out. So a belt would require a full redesign.  Using metal gears isn't worth the trouble since the hot end is too far away to melt the gears.  We have looked at some new designs. Dfarms Extruder addition is very good and should work well with the i3 Wades extruder.  See below vvvv

comments.text: I agree this does need to be Redone, This was a first attempt, and while it does work it's bulky. It would be a great feed for a Bowden. The main reason I made this is because in smaller extruder nozzles, .35 and .25mm, the filament really strips out often, due to the pressure required to push through the smaller hole.

comments.text: ok I got it, basically you take a stock or existing wades reloaded, then you add your idler which holds the bottom idler, and the top hobbed bolt, above the top hobbed bolt there is a hinge. you take the wades reloaded's idler and attach it to the hinge on the top of the top hobbed bolt. perfection, solves the idler tension issues, and makes it really easy to upgrade from a wades reloaded since it will only take the new idler and a gear. oh also the wades reloaded idler tensioners tension the whole new idler. anyways ill make it in inventor then ill give it a go.

This is a simple and fun fidget spinner I designed that uses one ceramic or metal 608 bearing and five 15 mm ball bearings. I am also including a 'Murican version that uses 1/2" ball bearings for my brothers and sisters in the US of A. Everything must be pressed fit together. It's a little tricky to get the ball bearings into place. I found it easiest to rest the spinner flat down on a table with a ball bearing hole leaning off the edge of the table. Then place the ball bearing on top of the hole and use a piece of wood or something hard to press it in with some force. Mine didn't break, but if yours does, increase the infill or try a different filament. It's probably best to use PLA or PETG so as to avoid warping. After that, press the caps in, give it a spin, and never be distracted by anything ever again.

This is a fresh project that I officially started earlier today. This is a prototype at best, but I figured I'd get all the dimensions hashed out while waiting on parts to arrive. This is intended to be an external enclosure for liquid cooling an MSI GS63VR notebook. I have a few design goals in mind with this project, aside from the benefits of liquid cooling. I want it to to be leak-proof, low profile, and completely reversible, and because it's a notebook, the liquid cooling must be modular with it's own power supply.

Dimensions are LxWxH
260mm x 156mm x 184.93mm

I'm going for a push/pull setup where ambient air is drawn from the top and vented through the rear.

My parts list.

Spare CPU/GPU heatsink
XSPC X2O 420 Single Bay Reservoir/Pump Combo
2x 120mmx25mm 12v Case Fans
120mm XSPC radiator
multiple quick disconnect fittings
two G 1/4 Bulkhead Pass through
12v fan controller
96 watt power supply (12v-8A) (overkill I know, but for future proofing)
A few other various parts, and some custom copper bending...lol

I already see four things that need to be changed so expect an upload soon.

description.text:
Designed after reading a post from the unofficial hypercube group on Facebook, Had problems with with prints no always attributed to "Z" banding issues.
It was the weight of the heatbed setup so now the whole weight of the heatbed assembly is sitting on the collar & not the coupling.

2 Versions, 1 has a cutout at the side which gives me an extra 15mm due to the aluminum angle assembly on my machine, the second version has no cutout.

Designed to take both 8mm & 10mm threaded Rods, 8mm Rod use a 608zz Bearing, 10mm Rod use a 6900zz Bearing ( or Similar ).
locate the collars 19 - 20mm from end of screw, this will place the threaded rod approx 8mm into the coupling assuming you have a standard 25x19mm coupling located approx 5mm on the stepper motor shaft.

title: LED Light Bar Front & Back CR-10 / CR-10S (No Screws Needed)

description.text:
I was searching for a simple no screws required light bar design for my CR-10S. I couldn't find one to my liking so I made one. Fits nice and snug on the top part of the frame. It has a little tunnel at one end for wires to fit through for connecting the two sides of LED's. At the other end, it has two little holes for putting wires through to make it look neater.

Directions:

Option 1:
All I did was run the wires down the back of one of the aluminum channels near the left z-Axis rod. Then I hooked it up to a 12v wall adapter and put a switch on it.

Option 2:
You could get power to the lights without using a 12v wall adapter is to tap into the extruders cooling fan I did this with my lights that move with my extruder (There will be a link to that model down below). All you have to do is cut the extruder cooling fan wires solder the LED light wires to it and solder back the extruder cooling fan wires to where they were connected before.

Switch Box:
I'm eventually going to design a box for the switch/s that will screw in with the spool holder.

Parts:
-12v LED Strip (or any LED's that use 12v)
-Wire
-1x Switch (Optional)

LED Light CR-10/CR-10s Fan Blower Mount: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2748757

LED's - https://www.amazon.com/Flexible-Non-waterproof-Christmas-Decoration-Daylight/dp/B00HSF65MC/ref=sr_1_4?s=hi&ie=UTF8&qid=1515286556&sr=1-4&keywords=led+strip

title: Bendy - Bendy and the Ink Machine

description.text:
Watch the video here for more information on how I created this: https://youtu.be/pZAenFM_dfE

It's time for Bendy! This is the drawing version of Bendy from the video game Bendy and the Ink Machine.

I modeled Bendy in ZBrush. I mostly used primitive objects like a sphere for the body and cylinders for the limbs. I just dynameshed them and sculpted them to shape. The head I did the same process but I used the subtract Boolean operation to cut out most of the details on his face. His hands were created using ZSpheres.

Bendy was sliced in Simplify3D and printed on the Robo R2 using Polysmooth filament. It was then polished in the Polysher.

Then Chelsey primed it with filler primer and painted it using a paintbrush and basic acrylics paints from our local hobby store. Then she sealed it with a glossy clear coat.

Printers: Robo R2
Filament: Polysmooth
Layer Height: 0.1mm
Supports: Yes

title: Mirror Sliding Door Track Guide
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a replacement part for a mirror sliding closet door in my house.

The upper track guide that is attached to the door broke a long time ago. The missing guide would cause the door to jam on the track if you used anything but light tension while closing the door.

The closet door is the original from 1980, so finding a replacement part was impossible. The original plastic piece was riveted to a metal bracket giving me no easy way to make an exact copy. I realized that the metal side frames of the closet door were hollow and that I could redesign the guide to slide into the frame.

After a couple of tries, I came up with this final design that works perfect.

I doubt anyone will ever use this, but I'm uploading just in case.

title: Coat Hanger Hybrid 3D Printer Kick Stand Design

description.text:
Coat hangers are great for all sorts of maker projects!

In this project I needed to create a 3D printed kickstand that could be incorporated into any of my future designs that would be easy to implement, robust and cheap to make and repeat.

Initially I tried to design the stand as a one piece 3D print and though it was an interesting (and frustrating) project, it wasn’t robust or stable and cleanup was very difficult.

Then came the coat hanger approach… watch the video provided to see how that works.

This product was designed as a drop in component for Fusion 360 to be added to any case or project I needed a kick stand on. I've used it in 2 projects so far and it's an awesome solution for a robust and steady stand.

Name：Notebook
Designer：Leonardo & Asil
Info：Snapmaker 3IN1 3D Printer allow the user to create much more wonderful projects. Especially when people work on hand-made projects. Here I want to share a hand-made project which made by laser and 3D printing tech.

More Information on snapmaker community : http://forum.snapmaker.com
The “Vintage Skull” was designed by @asil

Step1

Print the Vintage skull and engrave the notebook

Step2

Paint the Vintage skull
Polish the 3D print and then lay on a coat of paint. Repeat this step 4 times for a smooth surface.

Step3

Glue Notebook and 3D Print together

Tips

Using pencil to line out the boundary of picture. When you "Run boundary" on snapmakerjs making sure the laser can follow the line. It will insure that the picture engraved neatly on the notebook.

print_settings.Notes:: Wir wollten einige Plastik Teile aussehen lassen, als währen das Messingteile gewesen, die schon 100 Jahre in einer alten Maschinenhalle am werkeln waren. Um dies zu erzielen empfiehlt es sich keinen "perfekten" Druck zu machen. Ein bisschen Overextrusion im Top Layer sorgt z.B. dafür, dass die Teile eine schöne unebene Oberfläche bekommen.

description.text:
Time Freeze (Photo)box
English Version:
We decided to build an photo booth wich is a little bit different as the "normal" ones.

All 3D files are located in the Photobox.rar file. We have created the files with SolidWorks. If you want to change something and you don´t have SolidWorks then you can use OnShape.
You can find more pictures (and more documentation (actually only in german language....))
under:
https://www.toppoint.de/projekte/frickl/steampunk/timefreezebox/start

  • Generelles
    Warum sollen Photoboxen immer schlicht weiß und langweilig sein. Diese Fragen haben
    wir uns auch gestellt und uns im Zuge dessen dazu entschieden eine etwas andere
    Photobox zu bauen. Aus dieser Idee ist die Steampunk Photobox entstanden.

  • Druckdaten finden
    Sowohl die Druckdaten in .stl Form als auch die Originalen SolidWorks Dateien befinden
    sich in der Photobox.rar Datei. Sollte man kein Solidworks haben, dann kann die Dateien
    auch in Onshape bearbeiten. Die STLs befinden sich in dem Ordner Photobox_stl und
    sind dort nach den Seiten der Photobox sortiert.

  • Dokumentation:
    Eine etwas ausführlichere Dokumentation findet ihr unter:
    https://www.toppoint.de/projekte/frickl/steampunk/timefreezebox/start

  • Fragen?
    Bei Fragen könnt ihr mich natürlich gerne Löchern :D

Printer:

3Dison

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0,2

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Wir wollten einige Plastik Teile aussehen lassen, als währen das Messingteile gewesen, die schon 100 Jahre in einer alten Maschinenhalle am werkeln waren. Um dies zu erzielen empfiehlt es sich keinen "perfekten" Druck zu machen. Ein bisschen Overextrusion im Top Layer sorgt z.B. dafür, dass die Teile eine schöne unebene Oberfläche bekommen.

Messingeffekt

Nach dem Druck haben wir die Teile nur grob von Unreinheiten befreit.
Um einen "alten bzw. gebrauchten" Messingeffekt zu erzielen haben wir die Teile erst mit Plastikprimer vorbereitet und dann schwarz grundiert. Als Messingfarbe haben wir Wischmetall verwendet. Dieses wird einfach mit dem Finger aufgetragen.

description.text:
this is an adaptor for tDCS experiments in mice. it should be filled with with saline solution (NaCl 0.9%) before the stimulation to establish a contact area of 3.5mm2
I've designed it according to the one described in the paper "Pedron, S., Monnin, J., Haffen, E., Sechter, D., & Van Waes, V. (2013). author: Eolus

title: Servo Operated Bungee Release Key Chain

description.text:
This thing is a servo operated bungee release. It is used to hold the bungee while you set up your aircraft for bungee launch. The release mechanism is servo operated using a standard 9g servo.

You will need:

  • one 9g servo
  • two 2mm x 10mm self-tapping screws
  • one round metal pull apart keychain
  • two small cable ties

You can connect your servo to a servo tester to setup and test. I use this servo operated release mechanism to autonomously launch my flying wing model aircraft. I connect the servo to the aircraft via a magnetic connector and receptacle. At launch, the connector breaks loose from the aircraft, allowing the bungee release to be reprimed and prepared for the next launch.

title: Spool Holder for XYZprinting da Vinci 1.0 Pro
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a simplified version of the spool holder designed by Brian.
There are to versions of it:

  • one for normal 1 kg spools
  • one for bigger spools

Print it with at least 3 perimeters and 50% infill for strength.
You may drill the filament passing hole with 4 mm drill bit and insert a teflon tube through it. I'd suggest make it a bit longer and shape it so it will guide the filament from within the spool sides, just to prevent issues with filament coming out from full spuuls and get tangled around the axle.
There is also a small clamp that you can use to keeping the spool close to the back of the printer (particularly useful if you do not attach a teflon tube as above). Don't make it too rigid, or it will break when inserting into the guides provided in the axle.

title: Anet A8 - Rear Back Frame Splitted (Telaio Posteriore)

description.text:
Hi, this is the rear frame for Anet A8 for those who have broken the original one.
It is too long to be printed in one piece so i've splitted it in two parts with a male/female junction.
I've designed it 2mm thicker to make it strong...if u like u can scale Z direction inside your favourite slicer to make it like the original (8mm).
I've also closed the two holes where the plate rails are fitted.
Also add an extra triangle shape to both X sides for better support with the rest of the frame.

Ciao, per quelli che come me hanno rotto la parte posteriore del telaio.
La parte è troppo lunga per essere stampata intera per cui l'ho divisa in due parti ricollegabili con un giunto maschio/femmina.
Per rendre la parte piu' resistente ho aumentato lo spessore di 2mm rispetto all'originale. Chi vuole puo' variare lo spessore modificando la scala per l'asse Z direttamente nel software di slice preferito,
Ho anche chiuso i due fori passanti in cui sono alloggiate le barre di scorrimento del carrello, in modo da non dover piu' utilizzare i due 'sportellini' originali.
Inoltre ho aggiunto due rinforzi ai lati, in corrispondenza dell'unione tra il pezzo e le parti verticali del telaio

author: Variable-Visual

title: Customizable Random Snowflake (BlocksCAD)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is my snowflake which I made for the BlocksCAD Snowflake Challenge.

I included some random magic. Every snowflake looks a bit different. So you can change some values, click render and be surprised how it looks or just take one of the ready to print STL files.

See the picture above for the customizable input variables.

  • radius_flake is the length of one leg.
  • size_tip is a random value (1 or 2) to vary the size of torus bodies on the leg tips a bit you can try to change it but may get a strange looking outcome
  • thickness_inner is the (half) thickness of the centre of the snowflake (default: 1.5, printable: 1)
  • thickness_outer is the (half) thickness of the outer ends. Set this to the same value as thickness_inner for better printability (I have done so in the STL files) or a lower value to make it look nicer. (default: 0.5, printable: 1)
  • number_legs defines the total number of the legs. A usual flake has 6 of them. Change the value and be suprised about the outcome.

It's all about the number 6 and the angle of 60° (given by the formation of natural ice crystals). The base of the flake profile is a hexagon (cylinder or torus with 6 surfaces). If the number_legs is 6, the Angle between them is 60°. The rips are rotated 60° out of the legs and their lengths are randomized. In the inner third of the flake there are a maximum of 6 toruses. Which of them are shown is decided by a random integer. Last but not least, there are 6 rips per side on each leg.

author: Hensch

description.text: Ork Trucks for Epic, 6mm

This is a plug for a drain hole in a "Glide" junior kayak sold in Australia (model "tadpole"). I suspect other "Glide" kayaks use identical plugs but you are on your own there.

The threads match the "tadpole junior series" drain plug perfectly and the rim adequately seats an ad-hoc gasket into place between the plug and the boat body.

Adding more axial length to the "gear-tooth" grip finger tightening features may be useful.

This 3d file prints perfectly in alloy 910 (nylon) as-is. You should be able to print it without additional support or a raft as configured in the included .STL unless you are having printer or plastic issues.

Keep in mind that ABS rots in sunlight (UV degradation). Also keep in mind you will have to make your own gasket (i.e. steal an o-ring from something else or chop up an old sheet of sturdy rubber if designing/printing something in TPE sounds too irritating...)

Enjoy!
Test

title: Tronxy X1 Ball Bearing X and Y Stepper Motor Support

description.text:
These ball bearing mounts support the end of the stepper motor shaft on the X and Y axis for the Tronxy X1 3D printer.

The bearings are available here https://www.banggood.com/Wholesale-10Pcs-5-x-10-x-4mm-Metal-Sealed-Shielded-Deep-Groove-Ball-Bearing-MR105ZZ-p-62635.html

The Y axis stepper motor mount was modified to the move the end stop switch 15mm placing the Y axis home on the corner of the build platform. Also the recessed pockets for the nuts that retain the homing switches were changed to a hexagonal pocket to trap the screws from spinning, making assembly much easier.

title: Micro quadrocopter frame - semiducted - Beecheese frame V4

description.text:
Enjoy my new 3d design for a brushless micro quadrocopter. Based on the brushed quadrocopter idea of stlyesuxx. It uses 2.5 inch propeller and 2S lipo in combination with brushless dys 7000kv 1104 motors. The AUW of the micro quadcopter is around 140grams using a 850mah battery pack.
Thrust should be around 150 grams per motor with 2S and 2540 tribalde props.
So it has quite some punch :)
If you crash, it might break, but it still does an good job at protecting your components. Most times, you will be able to fix the frame using superglue or a print pen. Moving the components to a new print. is done wthin minutes.

My flightcontrolboard is flashed with betaflight 3.2.4 at standart PID settings and with dynamic filter enabled. Only rates are adjusted.

If you want to add a small action cam, you might need to retune your pid and fly acro a bit less hard. But it willy carry a mobius or runcam 2, so you get some nice 1080p footage from it.

If you have some flexible filament you may print the tpu motor mounts to reduce vibrations on your frame. For me this worked quite good.
You may also try to print the short standoffs using tpu. In addition i mounted my fc board onto slices of "oropax" earplugs. This works quite well.

You may mount all the usual FC sizes to this frame. 30.5mm, 20mm, 16mm
This setup is able to carry a runcam split 1/2 or runcam split mini.

It will fit M3 screws for the frame standoffs and the 30mm flightboards. (10x)
Use M2 screws for the flight boards with a diameter of 20mm or 16mm (4 - 12x)

I have also added a tiny bit screwdriver, in case you have troubles reaching the cam mount, you might find it usefull.

I would be very happy to see your make and get some feedback :)

Build and first testflights:
https://youtu.be/CC2rdLjDmQU

Will it freestyle?
https://youtu.be/pIXTmZT7Z0w

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=El74EtgDLiM

Betaflight 3.2.4 https://github.com/betaflight/ (Open Source)

earth

After my buddy Bowser broke his paw, I needed something I could put in his cage to hold tupperware containers for his food and water. I've included versions with and without holes in the bottom.

Modeled in Fusion 360. Print it flat on the bed with supports for the hooks. Recommend a higher than normal temperature to make sure the hooks have really good layer adhesion.

Mudd Guppy

This beautiful little creature is very elusive. Born late spring to early summer, the Mudd Guppy feeds on anything living and is not much of a scavenger
The best time to spot a Mudd Guppy is early morning or evening as the sun is going down.
This creature is native to North America. Like a bear, Muddy Guppy's will hibernate the majority of the winter, they do not like the cold but will bare it for a tasty snack on a cold winters night.
As the Muddy Guppy grows so does their hunger and thirst for the chase,
There have been tales of the Mudd Guppy nibbling on the toes of small childern as they sleep, but no official reports.
Rarely spotted the Mudd Guppy had went undetected for many years up until recently.
I have modeled the Mudd Guppy after the one and only photo on record.

Please post your makes and feel free to share your thoughts on this little wonder of nature.
I hope you enjoy making one as much as I did. :)

title: Tronxy X3a Y Motor mount flipped for Upgrade Bed
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a work in progress I haven't tested it yet --- This is a Y motor mount flipped for use with the Bed Upgrade parts. Use whatever print settings you like for your setup. the top and side are 3mm, the angle supports are 4mm. I made it to be compatible with the original t-nuts screws and motor mount screws. There is a little room between the angle brackets to allow for air flow cooling. Shouts go out to Create3DPrints on the TronXY X3 X Motor Mount for being the base Object that I started with and modified to get this Y motor bracket.

It turns out the screw holes are a tiny bit off and best thing to do is after cleaning up the inside corners and surfaces, align the first hole and mark with a pencil on top of the part, the direction of the next hole and use a drill bit the size of the screw ( 4mm ) and use the drill bit to slowly work the hole open by moving the drill back and forth and applying pressure in the direction needed for the hole to line up with the screw opening, and continue to slowly work the hole opening to fit the actual screw openings in the motor. It took me maybe 10 minutes when i switched to this method. The large hole in the center need to be cut back on the first (screw) side too, use a razor blade and work that down so the motor will sit flush to the top. At most three of the holes are off maybe 1mm for the greatest one.
Work one opening at a time and continually put the motor in, to check alignment/adjustment needed.

**** EDIT *****
i didn't find this before I created this part but big shouts out to kencam ( thingiverse.com/thing:2185364 ) who has a y motor mount on his parts for the bed upgrade. It probably has the screw holes in the exact right position so perhaps that part maybe better in this case, then dealing with post production work.

Tronxy X3A

Optional Printed Parts to upgrade a RailCore II to a RailCore IIZL

The full RailCore II project is here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2407174

The ZL option implements 3 point automatic bed leveling - physically leveling the bed using your Z probe and 3 independent Z steppers. This option requires a Duet Controller and a Duex2 or Duex5 expansion.

Details on the bed leveling as implemented are here: https://www.duet3d.com/wiki/Bed_levelling_using_multiple_independent_Z_motors

Using 3 independent Z steppers under the bed, each driving its own leadscrew, we've implemented 3 fully independent Z towers. These allow the controller to use a Z probe near each of the towers, and automatically level the bed.

Parts needed for the ZL option (and parts not needed from the standard RailCore II Build) are listed in the BOM Here: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1KvlSNYHE20HYjQlURdH50Pn_V7t8TfuNNLnhcvI4Nos/edit?usp=sharing

Fusion 360 CAD model for the ZL version is available here: http://a360.co/2DoeHFu

PLEASE NOTE: This is early in testing, and may change

comments.text: When deciding to build a Railcore II, does it make sense to start with a default model, en upgrade to ZL later if wished? Or is that a waste of effort and money? This leveling looks really interesting!
comments.author: ConHen

comments.text: If you intend to do the ZL option, it's cheaper to do it up front.  There are a few parts you end up not needing, and a few you probably want to replace. (The leadscrews are best TR8*4 on the ZL, to keep the same steps/mm in Z).  The biggest component you have to replace is the bed/carrier.  We have a new bed design for the ZL I've sent off to 713maker that will be a single piece install, so far more efficient and cheaper than the current bed/carrier combo.  But that'll mean if you build a standard using a bed/carrier, then upgrade, you'll be out some $ there.

Enter the Olight S1 (and recently S1R) EDC flashlight.
Smaller than your typical EDC light, the Olight is small enough to carry on your belt without becoming a nuisance.

description.text:
This is a holder to add a WebCam to the GynePunk Speculum.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:865593

The type of webcam that fits with this holder can be found on ebay (see Picture of Webcam). The case of the Webcam must be removed to fit the Webcam in the holder.

These aluminum gantry lifts replace the stock rail lifts and add 1 inch of space between the bottom of the stock Z-Axis rails and the bed.

The aluminum is 1/4" 6061-T451. A 12" by 12" sheet can be found on Amazon:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0147KXYNS/

I used the Solid Carbide Single Flute Upcut End Mill (30238-02) from Inventables:
https://www.inventables.com/technologies/solid-carbide-single-flute-upcut-end-mill#30238-02

Most PCIe riser boards come with a foam mat on the bottom. However if you prefer to fasten it to your rack/wood beam; then you can use this with zip-ties or screws to give your PCIe slot horizontal stability.

Most, if not all, riser boards to my knowledge have the same screw hole format. So they should be able to screw right into this stand-off once you fasten it down. If you are concerned, then these are the exact ones that I used with this print.

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0769VZ5Q2/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1

title: 3 Part x 5 Bight Turk's Head Knot Mandrel

description.text:
A boyscout woggle knot mandrel. Stick 1/8" pins in the holes (either cut 1/8" dowels to about 1/2"-3/4" lengths or print the included pin.stl file), then follow the pattern with a strand of cord. Once completed, remove the pins and the knot slides off. You can double or even triple the knot by following the knot around again with your cord (for best results, leave it on the mandrel while doubling or tripling). This 3D printable model was designed to look like the ones that I make out of wood with a Pocket NC. You can purchase the wood ones that I make here. Learn more about my CNC mandrels in my blog post.

I recommend printing the pin laying down as it can break easily in the holes if printed vertically. Wood dowels are even more reliable.

title: General Lee Vector-Style Wheels
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
A friend wanted some wheels for his RC "General Lee" build (from the "Dukes of Hazzard" TV show), so I designed some in the style of the original American Racing "Vector" wheels as there wasn't much available.

There are wheels to fit both regular 26mm touring car tyres, as well as HPI/Protoform's "Vintage" style tyres for a more authentic look.

The 26mm wheels come in two versions, one "regular" wheel and one with a wide lip. The one with the lip is so you can run 26mm tyres but, from a distance, maintain the look of more authentic 14/15" wheels.

The wheels are available in various widths and offsets:

  • HPI Vintage, 31mm wide, 0mm offset
  • HPI Vintage, 31mm wide, 6mm offset
  • HPI Vintage, 26mm wide, 0mm offset
  • HPI Vintage, 26mm wide, 6mm offset
  • Touring Type 1, 26mm wide, 0mm offset
  • Touring Type 1, 26mm wide, 6mm offset
  • Touring Type 2, 26mm wide, 0mm offset
  • Touring Type 2, 26mm wide, 6mm offset

I hope these are useful to people doing General Lee builds!

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2-0.05

Infill:

Concentric

Notes:

For best results, use a slicer with variable layer height (like Slic3r) and make sure the shallow curves inside the wheel are printed at as high a resolution as possible, e.g., 0.05mm. The rest of the wheel can be printed at 0.2-0.35 to maximize strength and cut down print time.

I printed mine in black PLA at a low-ish temperature for a more matt look, but probably best to print at the higher end of your filament's temperature range to maximise strength. That, or just bake them after they're printed. (No, really, see Tom Sanlanderer's YouTube video on the subject!)
Remove the supports and use either paint or a metallic Sharpie (or similar) marker to do the silver lines.
I designed these in what is still my favourite CAD tool, Autodesk 123D.

author: MikeKey

print_settings.Notes:: m51_g_all_edges_on.stl

title: Whirlpool Galaxy (M51)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a model of the Whirlpool Galaxy (M51). It is designed to help make astronomy accessible to students with vision impairments (VI) and is part of the Tactile Universe.

This model uses a single-band image of a galaxy as a height map with the height of the raised areas scaling with the amount of light emitted from the galaxy. In this model the SDSS g-band (blue light, ~475 nm) is used. The blue light from a galaxy shows the location of the hot and young starts within a galaxy.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Dreamer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

For the Dreamer we found the best way to print the models was with them standing on their thin edge (see attached photo). This makes sure that the resulting models are smooth and easy to interpret for people with VI. To avoid using supports the "top edge" of the model has been removed as a separate piece that can be glued on after the print is finished (the m51_g_top_edge_off.stl file).

We have also included a version of the file with all the edges still attached to the model (m51_g_all_edges_on.stl). This model can be used if you want to experiment with adding supports or printing it "flat side down" (only recommended if you have a printer with better than 0.1mm resolution in the Z direction).

1) Glue on external edge

After printing use super glue to attach the top edge on the model

2) Glue photo on the back

To help aid people with partial/full vision the black and white photo can be printed out and glued on the back of the model. The image is mirrored to ensure that the features of the 3D model and the image on the back are aligned when holding the model in you hands.

1) Image stretch

The original Sloan Digital Sky Survey data was processed using an arcsinh stretch, this helps bring out both the bright core of the galaxy and the faint spiral arms. The code used can be found on our GitHub page https://github.com/TactileUniverse/3D-Printed-Galaxy-Software/blob/master/make_images.py.

2) Use image as height map

Blender was used to apply this black and white image as a height map of a flat plane. A raised edge was added along the outside at the same height as the brightest part of the model to be used as a point-of-reference for people with VI.

We created a custom plugin (https://github.com/TactileUniverse/3D-Printed-Galaxy-Software/blob/master/emboss_plane.py) to automate this process.

The Tactile Universe is an award-winning public engagement project at the Institute of Cosmology and Gravitation, University of Portsmouth (UK). The project aims to make astrophysics research accessible to people with VI, with a particular focus on children aged 9 - 14. The Tactile Universe is different from other VI-accessible astronomy outreach projects in that 1) we are engaging the VI community with current research, rather than the more basic astronomy concepts like constellations, and 2) we are showing that astrophysics can be a possible route of study and future career, not just a hobby. The Project Lead is Dr Nic Bonne, who is a blind astrophysicist himself.

General Info
  • Distance: 23 Mly (1.35 * 10^20 miles)
  • Diameter: 60 kly (3.52 * 10^17 miles)
  • Contains 100 thousand million stars
  • Face-on
  • Central bulge
  • Two well defined spiral arms
  • Dust lanes run through centre of arms
  • Companion galaxy on end of one of spiral arms
  • Companion is odd shape due to interaction, and should feel flat due to absence of star formation
    • Guided tactile tour of the model M51 is a face-on spiral, and is also called the "Whirlpool galaxy". M51 has an interacting companion galaxy. If we start by finding the bulge of the larger galaxy in the pair (in the center of the model), then tracing around it, we should feel two distinct raised areas, both at opposite sides of the bulge. These are the two main spiral arms. Feel how much rougher they are than the bulge. One of these arms is much longer than the other, and if we trace it to its end, we should find the galaxy’s companion. The companion is actually exchanging gas and stars with the larger galaxy, which is why this arm feels so much longer than the other one. This companion is also very smooth, as its structure has been lost due to gravitational interactions and its stellar population is very old.
Super glue (for constructing the model after it is printed).

This model makes use of data taken from the NASA Sloan Atlas and the Sloan Digital Sky Survey. These data were processed using software developed by the Tactile Universe team, freely available on GitHub https://github.com/TactileUniverse/3D-Printed-Galaxy-Software.

The Tactile Universe would like some basic statistics for how our models are being used. If you use our model in an educational setting we would appreciate if you could send the following feedback to [email protected]:

  • how many people interacted with the model and how many were VI (if any)
  • any general feedback about printing or presenting the model

author: DMRadford

description.text:
Lil-b is a small 100mm x 100mm servo driven robot made for beginners. The bot is easy to print as assemble, having just a few parts.

It is made from 2 platforms (one top and one base), 2 wheels, 4 servo motor mounts, 4 standoffs and two Caster-slides.

Hardware and materials you will need to assemble:

  • 10x M3 screws
  • Super glue (for the motor mounts)
  • 2x 40mm x 4mm o-ring for the wheels
  • 2x Feetech FS90R or Adafruit 9g continuous rotation servos.
  • 2x servo horns (should be included in the servos)
  • Arduino with sensor shied or the like
  • 1x 7.4v lipo or other 5v or greater battery (a 9v battery will be ok)
  • 1x hc-sr04
  • Jumper wires (Dupont)

Directions:
Print all of the parts - 1 base, 1 top, 2 wheels, 4 standoffs, 2 slide-casters, 1 face and the four motor mounts.

  • Take the motor mounts and glue them as picture five and six (5,6) shows.
  • Glue the servo horns inside the hub of the wheels.
  • Glue the Faceplate in the slot of the top platform (note: you may have to file or sand the edges of the insert a bit to get it in) See picture seven (7)
  • Screw or glue the slide casters to the bottom of the base platform (the opposite side from the motor mounts). See picture eight (8)
  • Let all glue dry.
  • Mount the servos to the base platform onto the mounting posts using the mounting screws that came with the servo. The servo shafts will be closest to the rear of the bot.
  • Mount the standoffs to the base platform, using 4 of the M3 screws.
  • Mount the top platform to the base on the standoffs using 4 M3 screws.
  • Place the o-rings onto the wheels inside the groove.
  • Mount the wheels onto the servos, and use the little screw that came with the servo to secure the wheel on.
  • Add the Arduino and hc-sr04 to the faceplate.
  • Connect the servos and hc-sr04 to the Arduino.
  • Program and enjoy!

The base platform has mounting holes for up to three IR sensors for line following. If you use the bot for that, then forgo adding the front slide-caster.

Update: Added taller standoffs that will allow for a 2x4 aa holder.

Add test code. A simple obstacle avoider.

All the latest files are @ https://github.com/jscottb/bumpybot

Robo 3D

C2 R2

Print the standoffs, casters and servo mounts at 100%.
Print the wheels at 40-50%.
